review_body: Love location, rooms, beds, cleaningness, quietness, comfortability, good staffs, everything about hospitality is here, restaurants here has good food, chinese & BBQ, You have a japanese big temple, beside this hotel you can take a walk around which make this hotel very special with historical.

This hotel was an very good choice made by the travel company. The rooms are large and comfortable and there are enough lifts so we did not have to wait a long time to get up to our room or get out or go down to the restaurant. The wide choice of food, occidental and japanese, is excellent and really tasty.A minor minus : you are allowed to expect that body lotion is included in the toiletry but there was not! The view on the Tokyo Tower from our room was a very nice surprise.

Lovely hotel and location. Room was large with enormous and comfortable bed. Came for grandson's 1st birthday, who lives in Tokyo with our daughter and husband. In the main we were largely unaware of costs, so bring loads of money. Prices in the hotel are eye watering, £7.50 for a coffee, £10 for a half glass of local beer, £25 for a buffet breakfast, £40+ for dinner (all pp). Perhaps I should have researched more but reviews were on the whole good. Unfortunately we are in a commercial neighbourhood and alternatives to the hotel are not really viable.

Overall a great hotel. Rooms are dated (80s style) but well maintained and clean. A little pricey though for standard though... Didn't eat at the hotel other than breakfast as explored the local restaurants (with plenty to choose from). Great location and close to metro and train lines.

I checked in at 11.50am. They official check in time is 2pm but I would be out. So despite having rooms available they Want you to pay like 50$ more to use the room 1hr earlier . ( apparently 1 pm Is doable for free) I said only if u hv a free room and its done up already can I just leave my stuff and go out ? A firm no with that attitude was the answer .I’m leaving at 6 am in the morning . Isn’t that an early check out ? So can’t u accomadate my early check in?!?Staff seem stressed and used to giving that passive aggressive “can I help you “ kind of talk . I’ve seen them talking to other guests . For a 4 star hotel they hv a 2 star hotel attitude.

This is a very good quality hotel, of course the price is higher. The staff can communicate in English well. It is a bit far from the train station but there is a shuttle bus service for that. But the buffet is nothing special.

Rooms are old and tired, bathrooms paint scruffs and from 50’s..., check in staff/ front desk insufficient in check in handling. We came back 5 days after 1st stay in December and again there was confusion with booking. Price overrated and not in line at all with experience/ expectations. Never again

Stayed here four nights. Rooms are well laid out and views of a Tokyo Tower are terrific. Service is good. Access to most sights is easy with multiple metro stations. Good coffee shop nearby. Are well at nearby Mexican and Italian restaurants to have a break from local fare.

Stayed here for just one night following the rugby World Cup final and had a pleasant experience overall.The hotel is situated in a surprisingly quiet and pleasant location within this busy metropolis and a 10/15 minute walk to the main restaurant/bar areas. We arrived by train (very cheap) from Yokohama and left by train to the airport the following day. The train station was close by - a 15 minute walk - and the service to the airport was fantastic dropping you off straight into departures!The hotel is well presented, the reception we received very welcoming and the rooms are surprisingly large for Japan. They are also clean, spacious and functional.We didn’t eat in the hotel other than at breakfast where there was plenty of choice and the food was good.Would certainly consider next time in Tokyo.

It was daunting to plan our first trip to Tokyo, so I tediously studied reviews and finally booked our room at the Tokyo Prince Hotel. When we arrived at Haneda Airport we took the easiest, and cheapest route to take: THE MONORAIL - don't be afraid of the train, it is safe and a cheap way to travel. Step one: After leaving customs and immigration, head over to the monorail terminal on the left side. Purchase your ticket to the Hamamatsucho station. I think it's about 800 Yen (or about 8 USD) or chose to get an IC card from the machine and place enough on it for your return - my husband and I put about 1600 YEN on the cards (we bought two for both of us). Take the RED line to Hamamatsucho station - it will be the last stop. Once you arrive, follow the signs to the bus terminals at the station. It's not a far walk, just follow the signs. Get to bus terminal 5, which is at the end of the bus terminal (not far). Wait for the Tokyo Prince Shuttle. They will take you to your hotel for free. They do stop at another hotel, so make sure you get off at the right one! Easy! Check in was a simple process as we made reservations ahead of time, of course. They will take a credit card, but make sure you have cash (YEN) as almost every place will only accept cash. Wait until you change your money once you get to Japan and you may do so at a 7-11 ATM (yes, they have 7-11 everywhere!). We arrived at our room which was beautiful and had a wonderful view. The bathroom was well stocked with needed items, such as razors, toothbrushes, shampoo, etc. They even provided lounge robes for our stay. Everyone was so helpful and our room had a mini fridge, which we stocked well with snacks and drinks from the Lawson market located on the Basement level. We were close to the Tokyo Tower and also the Temple where Wolverine filmed the funeral scene! This made sightseeing easy and fun. I cannot express how truly great this hotel was and we highly recommend Tokyo Prince Hotel! Thank you to the wonderful staff for making our stay Perfect! Arigato!

We have been in this hotel at the beginning of the honeymoon to visit Tokyo. Location is perfect bacause it is very close to metro and the train station is not too far as well. Area is very calm and safe. Breakfast is very good and full of choices. Rooms are a bit too small for european standard but in Japan we found similar size in other hotel as well.

My room was very nice. Clean and comfortable beds. English tv was CNN. Got very tired of that. Would have been nice to have something with more variety. Very close to shopping and the people are amazingly kind and helpful. Everyone speaks a little English, but I suggest learning a couple of Japanese phrases. Had a welcome dinner in the hotel restaurant and it was pretty bad. Dried out chicken and boiled spinach. So many great places to eat in the neighborhood. One bad point. The bathroom tiles had a bad mold problem.

The hotel looks very austere from the outside but the rooms are fine. Whilst not too close to a subway station, the hotel is reasonably well situated.The breakfast isn’t up to much and the coffee is awful. Save some money and go to the coffee shop just at the end of the drive and to the right where they have a good selection of pastries and good coffee.The bar feels a bit sterile.The plus point is that the staff are very helpful

Ive stayed at this hotel many times over the years. I am writing this as I am in one of the rooms. Each time I stay it gets less attractive.The rooms on the lower floors have not been updated in years, and quite often on weekends the park next door to the hotel has bands playing that will wake you up. Ive had to change rooms a number of times due to excessive noise in the hallways as there are mostly non Japanese staying in the hotel. The staff is polite and helpful but the conditions are not great. There are MANY comparable hotels in the same area with better treatment that are quieter. I won't stay here again, and I would advise people to look elsewhere.

After a week of train travel in Japan, the Tokyo Prince Hotel offered comfort and elegance for this weary traveler. The staff was friendly and helpful, particularly with arranging a limo bus to Narita Airport. The hotel is located in an exceedingly quiet and non-congested area of Tokyo, next to the Prince Shiba Park and the iconic Tokyo Tower. Close proximity to the Tokyo subway makes exploring the city much more easier. There are many food options at the hotel; I had a fantastic meal at the sushi bar in the hotel’s Shimizu Japanese Restaurant. The convenience store on the ground floor was a surprise and a treat. I hope to stay again.

Tokyo Prince is a nice western style hotel in an upmarket part of Tokyo. Features are the range of on- site upmarket restaurants, nearby subway stations, nearby Tokyo Tower, nearby restaurant street and on-site connivence store. Negatives are the lack or room service, the on-site bars and restaurants close by 10pm, and there is a charge to use the swimming pool and no on-site Onsen.

Stayed at the Tokyo Prince Hotel in December 2018 for three nights on conference travel. The property is centrally located and the staff, especially Ms. Rosalind at the concierge desk, continues to provide exceptional service. Elevator service in the day is slow at times. The rooms have not been refurbished (the lobby is immaculate from the recent face-lift) but are still comfortable and well-appointed. Views of the Tokyo Tower were great.

Room was clean and service was okay. Stayed in a room on 9th floor. Make sure to request higher floor with view of Tokyo Tower. Breakfast buffet was good. Location is great. Rooms are expensive and pool was not so close to hotel.

Everything at this Hotel was Spectacular! From checking in, the location, cleanliness of the room, the Staff and shuttle services! Highly recommend staying here! If we ever visit Tokyo again this will be our go-to Hotel!

This hotel is next to the amazing Tokyo Tower. From our window we could see this tower and at night it was lit up with multicolor lights - quite an amazing site. There is a garden floor where the breakfast buffet is served and outside is a patio overlooking the tower where you can get food and beverages. This is a pricey hotel - but comparable to any in Japan. Within walking distance is a Pain restaurant that is very cozy and affordable - also a beer garden. Great location. Only problem is that you have to pay to swim in the pool or use the facilities.

This property is a very well located and has huge front porch to roam about. Rooms are very comfortable and spacious, staffs are cool, very accommodating. But they don't have any international hotels so that i could get my points added to my loyalty accounts. My points went unrecorded though i paid a lots of money as room rent. Also this one is a bit expensive in terms of International competition, according to Tokyo standard, price is ok though. I enjoyed pool, Karaoke, laundry, very good service all over

While difficult to narrow down ONE hotel out of so many I was fortunate enough to have found a prince of a hotel among the many!! From the moment we appeared until our final departure the service was stellar!! The room was spotless, beds extremely comfortable, plenty of pillows, blankets, towels, etc. The bathtub had a slanted back so it was actually comfortable to lay back in and enjoy. It was totally quiet with no noise from adjacent rooms or outside. The view was spectacular. Amazing proximity to subway stations, restaurants, (several options right on the property) convenience stores (a Lawson on B1 floor). Would definitely return and can freely recommend without reservation.

This hotel looks nice outside and on website only. Stay away and get your money worth elsewhere! Seriously! My family member book same as me but got better rooms that i did fir same price. My room was so outdated and has no in room coffee machine and the amenities are different. Room or housekeeping was rude told me to pay more for amenities in room. Spoke inconsiderately. I was so unhappy with the staff. Never stay here again. If you want to stay here, get rooms from 9 floor or better ! Do not stay 8 floor or below. You will regret it. Stay at other hotels like APA or Grand Centurion much better than Tokyo Prince Hotel! No pool included in your room reservations too! PLEASE DO NOT STAY HERE! It is a trick!

Booked here for business trip due to budget and available no smoking rooms. Dai-ichi annex in Ginza was closer to my vibe but only had smoking rooms. Solid place but not really a functional lobby to hang. There appear to be some things on site (pool, bier garden) but no explanation from staff on how these work / how to access. Rooms are kinda just rooms. Not many plugs. Main bar opens at 6 which is fine I guess. It’s not the Old Imperial but they make a nice cocktail and it’s worth spending an hour or two there. 2.5-3 out of 5.

Room are not equipped with any thing. Mini Bar is empty , only 1 tea bag for tea. lighting was not the best. and Very small room for the standard of hotel. Break fast is too crowded the need bigger space for the breakfast.

Rooms are smaller sized & very basic. TV channels are limited. But hotel is very close to Citi center.Also the in room tea coffee options are basic & limited to green tea only.No coffee in the room is disappointing

If you are here for business do not book this hotel. -noisy dirty rooms and full of tour groups. Told to pick breakfast up in Lobby ( but that is only open 9 to 11 - after anyone normal has left for work)Staff are indifferent - it’s impersonal and incredibly noisy. It’s my third time here —always pretty average but ok - now terrible. Will not stay again

Stayed at the Tokyo Prince pre Cultural Treasures of Japan tour with Collette Travel. Very conveniently situated near the metro and in a quieter area of busy Tokyo. Comfortable beds, good bathrooms, great breakfast. Staff very friendly.

This hotel is located in Tokyo tower area. In my opinion, this part of the city is a quiet place. Since it is attached to a public park and historical temple, I do jogging very morning during my stay. The hotel provides good facilities. They have upgraded their function and guest rooms. Breakfast and dinning restaurant services Western and Japanese style. The hotel has a swimming pool service with some additional changes during summer.Convenient store, Lawson, is located right at the basement and it opens until late.Free wifi is available all over the place with password required. The wifi signal is very strong and fast.Subway station can be found right in front of the hotel. The JR station is about 15 min walk. Large parking space is available with additional fee.

Nice clean hotel.we had king room with all amenities. Loved the location with subway in walking distance. Hotel was literally at the foot of the Tokyo Tower. The staff was helpful and spoke English. Taxi always available outside hotel doors.

If you're looking for a hotel with close proximity to all the major happening places in Tokyo, this one is not it. But I really like the quiet location, which is closer to business district. 10-15 minutes walking distance to train stations (which will get you anywhere). I stay for several days, as part of a tour trip. First few days was in larger and renovated room, and the later was in a smaller room. But both rooms were very nice and comfortable. I didn't have to more my luggage since the hotel took care of it right away after learning that I had to move to a different room (different reservations). Breakfast buffet had wide variety which will satisfy the pickiest eater (myself included). Service was outstanding and very customer oriented. You should try the Japanese restaurant in house. Very delicious and good quality meal.

We came here for a couple of nights during a business trip. Room size was really good and all facilities too. Wifi is also correct and the bathroom clean.Didn't try the breakfast and location is easy.

Location wise this is great. 15 minute walk from Haneda monorail, adjacent to subway and a beautiful park. The building's exterior has a 70s retro chic. However, the room was newly renovated. Oddly the smaller rooms had a view of Tokyo Tower but the larger rooms overlooked the carpark. Breakfast spread was amazing and delicious.

The good1) very close to tokyo tower2) has a family mart in the basement 3) good spacious lobby 4) great breakfast buffet spread 5) good rooms. Wifi etc The bad 1) there are no restaurants near the hotel. It’s a good walk to come close to civilisation. 2) the hotel looks a bit old from outside.3) the cafe on the ground floor is average.

Comfortable hotel very close to iconic Tokyo Tower. Several metro stations close by. Hotel has free wifi that works everywhere in hotel. Breakfast buffet recommended, friendly staff. Hotel bar quite expensive ¥1200-2300 for a drink.Transfer from Narita by bus shuttle service reasonable at ¥3100 each way and takes 60-90 minutes depending on traffic- but - offers free wifi on the bus ride!

Wonderfully located facility. Comfortable entrance, excellent staff and great room. All the amenities and in the heart of the city under the towering Tokyo Tower and peaceful Zojoji Temple. Room was a great size, the nespresso coffee machine a nice touch. Comfortable bed and a great view of the tower.The staff was helpful and worked with me and limited Japanese. Breakfast was plentiful, well prepared and the staff helpful and pleasant. Could not have picked a better location or a more friendly hotel. Thanks for a great stay!

Very close to Tokyo tower and several metro/subway links to have easy movement in Tokyo. Shutlle bus to and from airport costs JPY3100 each way, wifi on bus! Good breakfast buffet from 6.30 to 10.30am. Some staff have good english, rest typical for JP ie poor. Rooms comfortable, need refresh. TV has CNN and very few English channels. Small supermarket in basement. Enough cupboard/wardrobe space.

Popular tourist hotel next to famous Tokyo Tower. Rooms are comfortable but slowly need renewing. Twin bedded room. Enough wardrobe space. Bathroom OK, nice shower. TV little complicated with JP writing. Only CNN as English channel. WiFi free and very good. Breakfast buffet recommended.

Nice rooms, walkable to the subway, and great staff! Do take a taxi to the hotel if you have luggage, otherwise getting around by subway is rather easy. About a 15 minute walk to the subway.In traveling we do not demand that staff always speaks English. We understand that we are the foreigner.Staff was friendly and patient. Our knowledge of the Japanese language is limited and staff was gracious enough to work through any language barrier.Breakfast was outstanding. Large variety of fruits, pastries, eggs, and Japanese items. The omelets are outstanding.Rooms are called dated, perhaps because they have landlines in the bathroom.

We stay in this hotel every time we’re in Tokyo. The breakfast is very good and the rooms are clean and big for Tokyo. The hotel is very clean and they even support a shopping area in the basement with several shops. The staff is very nice and will help with anything.

This is a nice hotel for a business stay. Rooms have some dated fittings but are clean and the staff provide excellent service. The convenience store is also very handy. Location is quite close to Haneda Airport.

I write this from the point of view of a middle aged Australian spending two nights at this hotel. I have previously stayed in the Shinjuku and Shibuya areas.This is a much quieter area. The beauty of Tokyo is that all areas are easily accessed by train or metro so it doesn't really matter where you stay.This hotel is semi close to the Hamamatsucho station and several metro stations, but a little too far to walk from these stations to the hotel with bags. Fortunately, the hotel runs an hourly courtesy bus from the Hamamatsucho station. The hotel is medium priced, with a beautiful foyer. The rooms are good but just beginning to get a touch tired at the edges; nothing too bad though.The area between the hotel and Hamamatsucho station is excellent for dining; there are hundreds of options.One thing to keep in mind is that if exploring the close by [short metro trip] Roppongi Hills area/art triangle, and the Mid Town complex, is that most stores and galleries don't open till 10am or 11am so one has to find something else to do till late morning. I suggest the fish markets at Tsukijishijo.

Tokyo prince hotel is very close to Tokyo tower. I stayed there for 4 nights. Hotel is very close to Onarimon and Daimon station. Iconic Tokyo tower is just next to hotel and within close premises. Don't forget to bring warm clothes as it was quite cold outside !

we spent few days in the N building and few days in the main building. the N have small rooms but free breakfast and the main building have large room with large window and view. we liked the location and the quality of the servise. very good!

My recent stay was for a week, being a mix of business and vacation. The hotel is located very near the Tokyo Tower so easy to find!! First impressions are very good, this is a large hotel and the reception / restaurant floor is huge. Welcome was good and check-in very easy. Most staff had some English language and we certainly did not have a problem being understood.First half of my stay was in a standard room. It was a fair size (especially, as I understand, for Tokyo) but gave the impression of being a little dated due to a lot of wooded painted furniture. Maybe the effect was exaggerated in contrast to the huge, modern and luxury reception floor! However, the room was reasonably equipped, clean and comfortable. Later in my stay I moved to a Club floor room which was very much larger, better equipped and felt more modern (but a lot more expensive!). My slight disappointment in both rooms was that the shower was an 'over the bath' type rather than a walk in but I guess some people prefer the bath.The restaurants in the hotel are extremely good (at least the ones we used) but very expensive. There didn't seem to be much in the way of restaurants within easy walking distance of the hotel either. There is a small convenience store under the hotel in the basement level with very basic food, drink and general store options. It does usefully have a cash machine that accepted my UK cash-card.There is an airport limousine bus that regularly connects the hotel to Narita for 3,100 Yen. The hotel is also quite close to bus and three metro stations, enabling access to the city for sightseeing.

Good service, the breakfast are traditional and American. People always available to help you. The rooms are clean, with all the services and the bathrooms , American style . Just in Tokyo the room were small.

Nice enough and near Tokyo tower. But nothing outstanding. Convenient to have a Lawsons at the basement but it closes at 12.Beware however the tour busses and groups. Near enough to walk to Shinbashi. There is a metro station nearby but I did not bother.

I stayed here as it was walking distance to work. However, after work, the area is quiet, you'll need to take the train to other spot for dinner and shopping. Checking in was fast and the staff was very nice. There is a Lawson (it's the equivalent to our 7 11) with an ATM machine and quick purchases like water and breakfast (for those who has been to Tokyo, Lawson's breakfast is pretty tasty). The room is larger for Tokyo, but dated. I've been to Japan a few times before and in general all hotels in the past had been extraordinary clean, this hotel was just okay I comparison to the Japanese's standard, perhaps the age has something to do with it. Location wise you have the Daimon temple, and Tokyo tower, and a very good French cafe (for breakfast) but not much else. The hotel located near by Daimon station subway entrance, it is the easiest to get to and have more lines. You must get a Pasmo card when in Tokyo, subway is the easiest to get around, and Google maps work, it even tell you which platform to go, and how much. Tokyo is awesome and for me it is very safe, even at 5 am in the dark when I couldn't sleep and was making my way to the fish market to have sushi for breakfast - solo.

Hotel is huge, it looks nice, room is clean and neat but is a little dated. I had a room facing the tower so it was nice. Very huge spread at the buffet breakfast and all staff were very friendly and helpful

I had the pleasure of staying two nights at the Tokyo Prince Hotel. The location is excellent, close to a Subway Station (Onarimon St.) and a few minutes by taxi to Tokyo Station. The breakfast has a very large variety, and is situated in a very beautiful hall. But the highlight of the Tokyo Prince Hotel is the service of the staff.I had difficulty making a local call, and the staff sent one person to my room to help me. On another occasion, since I did not know how to write Japanese correctly and had to send some products through the post office, the staff helped me find the correct addresses. I would definitely recommend staying at this hotel.

I stayed here in November as part of a small group tour. I enjoyed the experience. The hotel is near several train lines. I used Daimon and Hamatschuo mostly. It's about a 10 minute walk from those stations. And its a quick cab ride from Tokyo station if you're coming in from Narita. I found the room space to be fine. Other reviewers have said it was small but compared to some other hotels we stayed in in Japan this was spacious. We had 2 in our room and never felt like we were stepping on each other. The hotel has a buffet breakfast in the morning. It was included in our trip so I don't know how much the cost is. If you don't get the buffet there is a coffee/pastry shop right outside of the parking lot - next to a shrine. And a Starbucks on the way to Diamon/Hamatschuo. There is also a bar on the first floor and the outdoor area next to the breakfast room serves drinks till 9:30. It' has a nice view of the Tokyo Tower which is lit up pretty at night. There is a vending machine on every floor which has so many things and a small convenience store on the basement level.

Stayed here over Christmas 2018. The hotel room comfortably fit 3 people. Very clean and tidy. Easy walking distance to transport. The hotel staff were always helpful. Even accompanying me to buy tickets and to help translate. Would recommend to all travellers. Will be staying again.

I am a regular here and must say that the hotel is really spacious and great value by Japan standards. The rooms are well maintained, the staff are excellent and extremely courteous, helpful. What the Hotel needs are better options for food and a Gymnasium - yes, there isn't any ... However, there are good parks nearby to take a morning walk or jog

Stayed here on my business trip several years ago. The room that was given to me was very spacious clean and full with amenities. Feel lucky to be able to stay in this luxurious hotel. Such a lovely memory

This is a hotel with a very convenient location to the metro, only 3 minutes walk and you can reach the metro station. Surrounding the hotel is the park area and if you enjoy quiet time after a whole day of work or drinks in another area, this hotel offers a quiet back home feel when you walk back to the hotel from the metro. There is a convenience store located at B1 of the hotel and you can treat yourself with ice cream or fabulous diary products of Japan.Service of the hotel is great. I have connected with the concierge about public transportation to the Haneda Airport, staff there are very helpful and provided their help and advice on catching my flight time. Also used their service for taxi when leaving the hotel, and the service from the staff there is seamless.

Near Tokyo Tower and a short walk to subway station to get into Tokyo centre. But we used the hotel shuttle to Hamamatsu-cho Station, which offered more possibilities. The hotel has restaurants, shops etc. Service was impeccable. Expensive coffee in the lobby cafe!!

The Tokyo Prince hotel has a striking lobby, the staff are friendly and the location (right next to Tokyo tower) is fairly convenient. The service was good, we were upgraded to a higher room thanks to being on our honeymoon which was a nice touch. The rooms themselves are particular small - a feature of many Tokyo hotels. We chose this hotel because of the location and barely spent any time in the room so this wasn’t much of an issue.We had breakfast one day which was quite varied but pretty average and much of the hot food was only luke warm. It was expensive for what you get. Overall it was a good experience, perfectly nice hotel in a good location with comfortable rooms. Best for people who aren’t planning to spend much time in their rooms and will be out and about most of the time.

Although it’s mostly a business hotel in a fairly quiet neighborhood the Prince is a good option for Tokyo. Immaculately clean, rooms are spacious with a lot of natural light. Large option of restaurants and the breakfast buffet is simply luxurious. A good address in an expensive and busy city. There’s no fitness but there’s a good spa with affordable massages.

review_body: Tokyo Prince Hotel is located at the bottom of the hill where Tokyo Tower stands, and next to Zojoji, which is the home to the tombs of Shoguns from Edo period The hotel has large foreground, where Le Pain Quotidien's hut situates and, during the summer, beer garden opens. It has a convenient store Lawson in the basement, which stays open until midnight. Price is the same with other Lawsons in town so it is very convenient for those who are staying at the hotel. The mini fridge in the room is not stocked, but you can buy what you need at Lawson.Staffs are hardworking and conscientious. This hotel seems to charge extended check-out by charging extra by one hour. It's check out time is 11 am, and I was told that the extension to Noon would costs about 20 USD, rather than provided free of charge. Room is small but clean, comfortable and efficient. It has small fridge, electronic kettle and coffee machine. The only area of improvement is in-room safe. It is small and probably laptops do not fit. The Prince Hotel chain has its own reward programme and you need to reserve at a designated rate to qualify for JAL or ANA mileage. Better partnership with mileage programs and international hotel chains will make it more attractive for international guests to stay at Prince Hotel chains.

review_body: This is a pleasant and comfortable hotel near Tokyo tower. For my purposes it was well located and the rooms were surprisingly large9 for Tokyo) albeit the decor is a little dated.The restaurants options could be better described, but over all very pleasant.

Initial impression was average, staff at Front Desk was average was not really greeted with the Japanese Hospitality. Until the follow day, when I came back from office and it was raining so I took a taxi. Unfortunately left my umbrella in taxi and helplessly looking at the taxi driving away. At this moment Matsumoto San the bell boy came to me and enquire if I needed any help. After he heard, without a thought he ran towards my taxi in the rain and grab my umbrella and handed it back up me. Thumbs up for Matsumoto San, he made my stay in Tokyo a blessed!

I prefer a hotel close by the park. Shiba-Koen, I thought, was not a bad choice because of its central location in the city. I knew this hotel was old and operated by the local company (which may be slow to catch up international hotel changing standards in time). I have stayed many 5 or 4-star hotels in Tokyo for the last twenty years. The TA reviews about this hotel also gave me a very mixed feeling before I checked-in. Here are my observations for recent three nights stay. Pros: - Location: easy access to Tokyo Tower and the underground station (Onarimon station- operated by Toei, not a big subway operator comparing Tokyo metro). - Room size barely acceptable (considering Tokyo situation)Cons:- Local staff's poor English communication capability everywhere - Literally no true concierge services (because of a language barrier and lack of training for this services)- Very small bathroom (not a room, it is a bath module with a low height. big western people may be very difficult to have a proper shower), poor shower mechanical facility- Club lounge (not convenient, in a far corner of lobby floor with no windows at all, meditation room?... Minimum beverages and no hot dishes...Never experienced this kind of lounge in my life.) - Chance of being bumped into a large unmannered loud tour groupOthers- Breakfast was acceptable (Western, Asian, a few vegitalian..)My unpleasant case: - One morning, I stopped by the concierge and asked about the Toei-bus route (the largest bus operator in Tokyo) map because I was sick of moving around in the dark underground. At first it seemed to me the local staff (Mr. Maeda) did not understand my inquiry in English (I asked two times) he suddenly showed me a big Tokyo tour guide pamphlet which carried only sub-way routes. I asked again with more clear and easy English words - B U S.. Route.. M A P.. He threw the pamphlet on the desk with a noise, again. (Oops-) I called out the duty manager and complained.. only to found out that I could not get the proper simple concierge service..... No one wants to start the day with a very unpleasant memory. I am the guest paid a regular room charge. Well 1) This incident changed my general feelings of Japanese manner and hospitality which they have boasted of a long time 2) How will they host 2020 Tokyo Olympic games with this kind of manner? Stayed September 2018, as a business tripNot recommended to Western travelers with a minimum tolerance of language problem. also not recommended to any travelers expecting good club lounge facility and services.

Very old hotel, checked in and the staff lost part of my reservation, then joked about getting it wrong, then said there was absolutely nothing they could do. None of the electronic conveniences of a new hotel. And don’t let the pictures fool you, the rooms are not that nice. Please take your money and spend it on a hotel that’s nice and puts the customers first. And they can’t speak English. They were so afraid and intimidated to help a foreigner their hands were shaking.... I will never stay here again...

Good hotelVery courteous staffNo room serviceVery Limited Vegetarian foodGood location Very nice view of Tokyo TowerClean roomsTraditional Japanese hotelOld construction Has a convinience store that is open till 12 Midnight

As my title states, the one thing that stands out with this hotel is that their rooms are big. Considering how small hotel rooms are in and around Tokyo, in Shibuya or Roponggi or similar, the rooms in Tokyo Prince hotel is a very plus that compensates for its location. Some people say the location is excellent. That is a subjective opinion. It is near or next to the Tokyo Tower, and my room had a view of the tower. It is next to a subway station. But the surroundings are not really designed for the typical travellling tourist. The next bustling place is at least a subway ride away, although we did walk for something like almost 2 kilometers to get there.

It’s a good traditional hotel in Tokyo. Very well located and with big rooms. Polite friendly staff. Perhaps it could use some renovation in common areas making it more attractive or some updates in the rooms like painting or new furniture. Anyway, like all landmarks it’s surrounded, the hotel itself is a Tokyo landmark and worth the visit

The hotel is in the area around Tokyo Tower which is a welcome break from all the hustle and bustle of Tokyo with its parks and the nearby Zojo-ji temple. Although the hotel is a bit dated, the check-in service was wonderful and staff were very pleasant. As per Japanese hotels, rooms are small by Western standards, but very comfortable. Although I was on a lower floor, I still had a great view of Tokyo Tower. My only minor complaint was that there was water stains on the bathtub fixtures, but this was a small detail compared to an otherwise very relaxing one-night stay. Overall, I would recommend to anyone looking for some peace and quiet in the middle of city, but still very close to public transportation.

The staff are very nice as is customary in Japan. The pool is not free. And closes at 5pm to children.Rooms are nice with great views. Next door is the Tokyo Tower.There is a shop at the basement of the hotel like a 7-ll and very handy.Comfortable bed and good sleep,Close to Onarimon station.

We stayed at this hotel a week, and enjoyed the excellent service. The reception desk and information desk will do all they can to help. The only limitation is the understanding of English. The rooms were nice with an amazing view of Tokyo Tower. Old bathrooms but that did not bother us. All in all a great place to stay!

Stayed 5 nights at the Tokyo Prince Hotel. It is located in an excellent location directly behind the Tokyo Tower in the heart of Tokyo. You have nearby subway and train stations at your disposal. From the Haneda Airport you can take the monorail from the international terminal directly to the Hamamatsucho station for only $4.50 US per person. From the station, you can then either take a short cab ride or walk about 15 minutes, depending on the weather and amount of luggage. A taxi to the hotel from the airport will run you about $100.00. On your return trip, the hotel offers a free shuttle to the Hamamatsucho station every hour on the hour. In addition, you will find nearby restaurants with a lively night life. The hotel staff is wonderful and is always at your disposal. It has fine Japanese restaurants with very nice settings. The breakfast buffet is very complete, and they make a big effort to serve some western type meals. Some floors have rooms that have more updated furnishings. The rooms are very clean, housekeeping service is excellent; however, compared to US standards the rooms are quite small. Yet, for the time spent in the room, it’s fine as you’re out and about most of the time.

We were given a high floor room with an excellent view of Tokyo Tower. The room was comfortable and warm, although the bathroom was a little dated. We appreciated the shuttle bus that ran approximately every hour to the monorail station, and used it every day. We managed to cram luggage for six people in it including skis, (albeit without any assistance from the driver) and still leave enough room for others. The buffet restaurant was excellent and the karaoke section was a hoot, (it was the only place we could get food on our first night due to our late arrival).

This is big hotels with several tower and I think more than thousand rooms. It was all in the area; mall and offices, you can get anything you need inside. The room was okay, the breakfast place was very big and have several alternative place. It was really not simple hotel especially when you are first time because I also lost several time here..,

The service was terrible..... the door man (actually it was door woman)was not nice at all and she was so mean... can’t believe that the hotel place such a worst person at the entrance of the hotel. I’ll never come back to this hotel. Out of this experience I really loved here in Tokyo. So sad to close the experience of Tokyo before heading to the airport

It is rated highly, but I can't think of a better place to stay in Tokyo. We were close to everything as we were halfway between Tokyo Station and Shinjuku on both the Marinouchi and Ginza lines, which were a 1 minute walk away. The other nice thing is that the view from so high up from the rooms allows you to avoid lines at the Tokyo Tower or other sights to view the Tokyo skyline. The night view from the room with the wall to wall window is a great way to end the day. Our room included breakfast which was very good. I used the gym and pool and those were both above par by Japanese hotel standards. Finally, the staff was incredibly helpful, especially Mie H, who was able to help us see Mt. Fuji before we left. She really went above and beyond what was necessary. We will stay here again when we return to Tokyo.

review_body: This hotel has been thru an interior renovation. It was a luxury hotel back when, and the update (whenever that was) helps it regain that status. Bits of the classic Tokyo Prince Hotel remain here and there, such as the large mosaic wall in the lobby and gilded tiles and solid marble in the public restrooms. As for the guest rooms, the “Club” floor room was lovely, but cant speak for the other floors. The private lounge for club floor guests is a quiet space with minimalist refreshments (see pic). The staff is multinational and utterly well-trained in the Japanese art of hospitality. Can’t say enough good about them!

I stayed at the hotel for 4 days for business. It is in a very convenient position for the Toranomon business area. It has a shrine with gardens just outside and is 5 minutes away from the tower of Tokyo, so even with a little time, I could do some tourist activity.The staff is really professional and kind and the tempura restaurant at the first floor is excellent. The room are bigger than usual Tokyo standard and the price very reasonable. There is a Spa at the 3rd floor: I tried the foot and leg massage and it was a blessing after a 13 hour flight. It also has a convenience store in house.

This hotel has everything perfect about it . everything perfectly planned and in place . staff is good and well trained , Rooms are perfect - not too big - not too smallvery convenient location to go to Tokyo tower and good Tokyo life nearby . recommended for a perfect stay`

Location, beautiful lobby, comfortable rooms with a convenience store and 2 great restaurant/cafes.This hotel has great service but it’s no-frills: there is no room service but there is plenty of food and drinks in/out of the hotel.I’d definitely stay again.

This was by far the most comfortable hotel Of the 3 hotels I stayed at during my visit to Japan. It is perfectly situated next Zojiji Temple and Tokyo Tower. When I go back to Tokyo this will most likely be the place I stay at again. Service was impeccable. Breakfast buffet was tasty. Definitely a great experience.

I booked superior double room, high floor through Agoda, and I was given a room on 10th floor, which was the highest of this hotel (except for the lounge floor).Hotel is nicely old and classic, and you can feel that this hotel is quite high-end. I loved this hotel so much more than I expected. I once stayed at Intercontinental Tokyo Bay, but Tokyo Prince Hotel is waayyyy better! The room condition, staff, the view, everything! I personally thought the cheapest room of Tokyo Prince Hotel was even better than Club room at Intercontinental Tokyo Bay.Tokyo Tower view was fantastic! I was afraid I might see the only part of Tokyo Tower because it is so close to the hotel but I could see the whole Tokyo Tower, loved the view and could seat there and watch it forever.Tokyo Prince Hotel was beyond perfect up until I met the rudest hotel staff in my whole life! I went down for the breakfast, I admit it was super busy sunday morning, packed.There were tables along the window to see out the garden, but the tables were all taken and I was informed to seat at the sofa at the back, which was fine.Later I saw that the table along the window was empty so I walked to a male staff who was cleaning the table and said 'Excuse me' in English. Then, that male staff didn't even bother to look at me and yelled at me "NO!". NO what? I only said Excuse me with a smile. He couldn't be bothered to deal with me and he waved at other staff then she came to me, walked with me back to my table and explained that this table along the window is only for 3 or more people. So I said I understand that now, and thank you for kindly explaining that to me, and that male staff was super rude. (The kind female staff was Miss Ryuda, European who can speak fluent English and Japanese). She tried to cover that he isn't normally like that but he did only because it was busy morning. I still don't think that gives him a permission to yell at a customer. I have never been yelled at a hotel, even at the crappy one. This was definitely something you don't expect from 4~5 star hotels, and definitely not from Tokyo Prince Hotel.Tokyo Prince Hotel has its history, its pride to be one of the oldest hotel is Tokyo, and the perfect Tokyo Tower view but the whole thing can be ruined by one staff who thinks he can yell at a customer if he is swampted at work.I talked to the front desk while I was checking out about this, I didn't have much time and there was no manager available at that time, so instead of complaining at their face I wrote a very very long customer feedback. Hope the general manager received the feedback. I still can feel the anger when I think about what happened at the Tokyo Prince Hotel. I loved this hotel so much but I don't think I want to recommend this hotel to my friends, after what I have been through.

I stayed in this hotel with my daughter from 19th-25th Feb 2018 nothing special arrangements based on our length of stay.The only issue is because of one of the staff named Mariko [--] neglected to arrange my request, a surprise cake and flowers for my daughter 18th birthday (the highlight of our trip) due to her lack of follow-up and mis-communication. It was delivered at night instead of early morning. The Hotel manager (Mr. Koji) apologized and drove us by himself to Disneyland, provided some drinks in the minibar and assist to arrange the taxi on our check-out date going to the station.As I am working in the hotel industry, i would suggest to this hotel the staff should not argue with your guests just to cover your mistakes. proper training and must explain to the guests what and where are the Hotel facilities apply personal touch upon check-in.The rests are fine, tokyo tower just behind the hotel, some staff are friendly and others are snobish. Walking distance in some train station. Were given 2-days complimentary water to compensate their negligence. Special thanks to Mr. Koji.

I rarely wrote any negative comments, esp somewhere in Japan. We have double check with hotel concierge about the airport bus. Before we started our last day visiting, the concierge respond “ok bus follow timetable”, so we left our luggages in the storage. While it’s about afternoon, we return to the hotel and ready to get on bus, but there is no any airport bus. By the way, this hotel location is not convenient, so it will be very difficult to pull luggages to any public transportation. After couple minutes, the other concierge came out to the bus stop and asked if we are heading to the airport. Unfortunately, we have just informed at the moment that airport bus need to be reserve before a day. Lastly, after be informed there has no any bus at the moment and we have asked hotel to advise what will be other option to get to airport. The respond is very unfriendly and difficult communicate in English. However, it is kind of hard to imagine this situation could happened in Japan.

I have stayed at both Prince Hotel and Princes Park Hotel . Both are within 500 metes of each other and within a 5 minute walk to the iconic Tokyo tower. Princes Park hotel is more expensive but for that you get to stay in a more modern and upmarket hotel. Nicer rooms better breakfast buffet selection and stunning views. Prince hotel by comparison is a 3 star compared to a good  4 star. Its still nice and for Tokyo hotel accomodation value for money. Rooms especially by Tokyo standards are are good size. The hotel is getting a little long in the tooth and coyld do with some modernization but havinf said that they are clean and comfortable. The staff are a big plus very polite ans attentive. That aplies to both hotels. The location is very Handy to a good selection of restaurants and the Metro train system all within 10 minutes walk. I love walking aroing the side streets to eat in one of the many small traditional restaurants always an experience not to be missed. My top tip if you can have the choice and are staying more in central Tokyo fly into Haneda Airport rather than Narita Airport . Its so much closer and handier. Prince Park hotels are both connected to Haneda Airport with Bus Limousine service that will take you to the airport for 950 yen. A taxi is about 20 minutes in light Traffic and cost around 6500 yen. Depending on your budget both hotels are worth staying in.

This was the last hotel of a very long trip and I only needed it for one night. With so many other chooses in Tokyo I regret choosing this one. My flight in was delayed so I didn’t make it to the hotel until after 1am. While checking in I asked if I could check out an hour later so we could get some sleep. I was lectured by the desk man that I need to check out at the stated time. He went and got his supervisor, who lectured me also. I was tired and just wanted to get to bed. I wish I never asked for the extra hour because that ended up costing me 30 minutes and I went to bed very frustrated. The hotel itself isn’t that bad. There is a high charge to use the pool, which was closed during my visit anyway. The hallways are dark and have a dingy feeling. The bed is comfortable and the rooms are good sized. The bathrooms are very small, almost to small. The location is pretty good for sightseeing. I will never return to thisHotel and I suggest finding a different one.

I was here on business for a couple of days and found this hotel to be extremely nice - courteous staff, spotless rooms with a nice deep bath and very quiet at night, a big plus. It’s also not too far away from the central districts and the metro is easily accessible from there. As an extra bonus they had a Lawson’s supermarket in the basement, so you can buy snacks at any time. The rooms are a little small but unless you’re planning on spending a lot of time sitting in your room, it doesn’t really matter.

I stayed here over Christmas, and had read bad reviews which kept comparing it with the likes of Hilton. The thing is, it's not a Hilton. I arrived here from Kyoto and was greeted by helpful staff who took my bags and sorted out transfer luggage also. The house keeping staff are amazing, and everyone here is incredibly polite.Sure, the rooms are a tad dated and the bars and tea area are a bit soulless. But, this hotel has a nice air about it, as soon as you arrive, the location is perfect and the rooms are more than fit for purpose. I used one of the bars downstairs when I first arrived and the shop many times. Staff were really helpful I would come here again.

This hotel has spacious rooms and the price is also reasonable compared to room size. Although the hotel itself is rather old, it has been kept clean. All twin rooms are tower view, so keep that in mind if you make a reservation.방은 다른 도쿄 호텔에 비해 넓고 가격도 괜찮습니다. 오래된 호텔이라고 들었는데 내부 시설 상태도 괜찮았구요. 문열면 바로 도쿄타워가 보여 전망도 좋았습니다. 트윈룸은 다 타워뷰라고 하더라구요. 예약할 때 참고하시면 좋을 것 같습니다.

We recently stayed in this hotel for two nights during our visit to tokyo. So we were glad on the location of the hotel. It is located just next to the tokyo tower park and we can see tokyo tower from our room. Room was small as the norm in tokyo hotels. Regardless, the hotel’s building was good. The service though... oh boy. Housekeeping was bad. We came back to our room finding our clothes was being thrown to the side tables and our luggage being pushed aside without being put back which is probably for facilitation of cleaning up the room. So I guess, the hotel does have a good product, but bad service.

Stayed here on a business trip recently. The rooms are spacious and the hotel is very impressive even though it has a fairly old feel to it. The service was great too. My only complaint was that there is no in-room dining which was a bit of a bother. But otherwise, great hotel! Would recommend it.

If not for the breakfast, would have given a higher feedback !Hotel is very old, but they keep it nice. The delax rooms are very comfortable and nice size. Lobby is beautiful and location is so so... not much at all of dining options around the hotel.Was surprised at the low quality of the breakfast. After that experience, did not want to try any of the other restaurants in the hotel. Plenty of food in the breakfast, but nothing really is good. All cheap ingredients, basically same breakfast quality as any cheap business hotel in Tokyo. Buy a 500 yen breakfast in a convenience store, believe me, much tastier.

My family and I stayed here for one night while in Tokyo. It was a last minute two room booking because my sister was unwell. We requested to check-in early so that she could lie down. Not only did they facilitate this at no extra cost, they managed to put us in two rooms right next to each other with an amazing view of Tokyo tower! The service was great, everyone was very polite. The Lawson at the bottom of the hotel was very convenient. The bakery that is part of the hotel was perfect for a takeout breakfast on the go! The location was great, near to multiple stations and food options. I would definitely recommend this hotel and would stay here again.

I was traveling for business and stayed at the Tokyo Prince Hotel. Rooms were very spacious, beds very soft with excellent bedding. My toiletries were refilled daily which was nice since I was there for 5 nights. I had a 9th floor room which overlooked the entry way and driveway- very well decorated for Christmas with lights lining the drive. Convenience store located on the lower level of the hotel which I frequented- great for snacks, drinks, and the occasional lunch. I didn't do the hotels breakfast as this seemed very pricey compared to other options. Close to multiple train stops. I was traveling alone and felt completely safe walking around this area alone. I would absolutely stay here again!

The hotel was about what I expected for the center of Tokyo but was pleasantly surprised at how quiet it was. The location is good for walking to nearby restaurants and sites which is good because there is a very limited selection at the hotel, they just don't take dining very seriously as a service to provide to guests, they leave it to you to find something else. I was pleased to find a Le Pain Quotidien western style bakery restaurant at the far end of the parking lot (100m walk from the front door). The hotel wifi connection was really strong in my room on the 4th floor and in the lobby.The rooms are a bit on the small side, including the bathroom which was cramped. All in all, a very average place to stay but perfectly clean and safe.

I'm staying in the hotel right now - it was booked by a member of my staff who is Japanese. Sadly I'm not. Perhaps its fine if you are Japanese, but if you are used to Western hotels with western standards - it's pretty awful. Arrived after lunch but was hungry because no lunch had been served on the plane and I was jet lagged. Most of the food options in the hotel were closed and there is NO ROOM SERVICE!!!! Eventually found a snack in the lobby bar. Later that evening visited the buffet restaurant for dinner... but left because the buffet was awful. Very poor choices for a very expensive buffet price - maybe only 2 or 3 main course options on the buffet! This morning had breakfast in the buffet restaurant - again pretty poor choices (better than last night though). A few limited western options, at least, some fruit, some toast, pancakes and something approximating to bacon. The room I have (deluxe room) is plenty large enough, but very old. The desk has no plug sockets. There is no air conditioning so the room was very hot last night (I managed to get the window open a crack, but its still hot in here). Bed is comfortable, but the twin beds are narrow single beds rather than the more usual doubles. The soundproofing of the rooms is non-existent - last night I was kept awake until 2am by the people (at least 3 voices) in the neighbouring room. I eventually knocked on their door and asked them to be quiet. Similarly, when I was trying to take a nap in the afternoon, the noise from people shouting in the corridor was deafening. Its surprising in Japan to find such a poorly designed hotel. The bathroom is both tiny and clearly ancient although there are plenty of toiletries provided. Neither a proper bath nor shower - just one of those japanese half-tubs with a hand shower - which I would not expect in a hotel of this price. The convenience store in the basement is - well - convenient. The location is fine because my client is in this area and it's a 10 minute walk to the Monorail to Haneda airport. Nice park grounds and temple next to hotel. Airport bus takes 40 mins (apparently, did not take it yet) but this is slower than taking the monorail to Haneda. There is also a bus to Narita. On balance I would not stay here again.

review_body: The deluxe double room on the 10 th floor was spacious and with a Nic view. Breakfast buffé was generous and with lots of choices for all tastes. The terrace with the view over Tokyo Tower is fantastic, even though we stayed in rainy November.Close to 2-3 subway stations and a shuttle service to airport.Our friend go a family room but were a bit disappointed with size.Don't you just love the Japanese toilets!!!

A group of family stayed in this Hotel 3 times (in and out) during October and it was rather sad. Used to stay here a lot and then they renovated, actually what I call a "Claytons" renovation. Lobby and part of room renovated but basically same old hotel.Bathroom not touched, no air-conditioning as such just pumping warm air. To charge these amounts even in Tokyo rooms need to be air-conditioned when its hot outside. I spoke with the Duty Manager about my concerns but no comment he just listened. The staff seem to have missed the service issue since re-opening. Bottom line I will NOT be staying their again, heaps of better hotels for similar price range.

A hotel with a longstanding tradition it clearly shows its age but is still recommendable. Nested between Shiba Park and Tokyo Tower and next to Zojoji Temple (funeral temple of the Tokugawa shoguns) you almost feel you are in a green oasis. Some of the rooms can feel small from a foreigner's point of view so if you have problem with that you reserve a bigger room from the start. Bathroom and toilet are separate (as is customary in Japan) although the bathroom clearly shows its age.As is also customary in Japan you do not need to bring any toiletries as everything (even toothbrush and shavers) is being provided. If you like to enjoy a view of Mt. Fuji ask for a room facing Tokyo Tower (and hope for clear skies). The sunset can be spectacular.

A nice hotel with a wonderful view of the Tokyo Tower and nice garden next door.Pros:- Nice and decently well managed hotel- Very decent size room for Tokyo standard Cons:- Slightly out of the way. Feels like in the middle of nowhereA good hotel but will find it hard to come back to as there are plenty of choices for similar priced hotels that were more convenient

We stayed in room number 2324. When we put two beds together, there was a lot of dust under the bed((((( please,clean it!! Two small bottles of water in the room number cost 760₽ and there was no information about it. Of course, it's a monnaie but usually in 5 star hotels it's for free!

Located right next to Onarimon tube station, convenient to large number of restaurants near Daimon tube under 1km away and set right next to the "tower" which is not necessarily a positive depending on your point of view. Room was reasonable size for Japan with everything there and functioning. Massive rose, dahlia, carnation and other flower vase right in the middle of the lobby provided a visual and scent sensation with each visit. Pretty good overall.

A big hotel with a huge lobby. Nice helpful staff, communicating in English is no problem.Location is ok. Subway stations 400-800m. Taxi from Tokyo Station is ¥1300. No disturbing traffic noice. Taxi stand just outside the hotel. Convenious store (Farmers market) 400m.Lots of good restaurants on walking distance. Tokyo Tower is located on the back side.Breakfast a bit overpriced, ¥2420 incl tax. Both continental and Japanese style available.Le Pain Quotidien located close by should you like to vary your breakfast selection.Rooms are clean but a bit old fashioned and worn down. Time for refurbishment. Sheets are like fine sandpaper and pillows are hard and high.Conclusion:Ok hotel but expected more bang for the bucks.

Fantástico! Um hotel super bem localizado, a poucos metros da Tokyo Tower, perto da Estação de Metrô de Hamamatsucho e bem lado do templo Zozoji. Café da manhã excelente e super variado, com opções de comidas japonesas e ocidentais. Tem piscina, mas seu uso é pago. Quartos com bom espaço, camas muitos confortáveis, staff muito prestativo. Não tenho nenhuma reclamação sobre o hotel.[English] Fantastic! Very good location, near Tokyo Tower and Hamamatsucho Station and next to Zozoji Temple. Excellent and varied breakfast with japanese and western options. There's a pool, but you have to pay to use it. The rooms are not small (some of them are really spacious) and the beds are very comfortable. Friendly staff. I have nothing to complain about this hotel

Wasn't sure about the location but turned out to be very hand. Shuttle to station every half and hour. Good eating within 800 metres at reasonable prices. Hotel was excellent, staff great, so obliging . Room smallish but great view of Tokyo Tower. Club room provided a good hot breakfast and snacks during the day and evening. Drinks including beer all day. Was easy to get to from Yokohama cruise terminal with a direct train. Also a bus to Narita Airport at a reasonable cost. Will stay here again

Room was nice size, not the typical 'tiny' Japanese style room.it was open, airy, with large window with good views. The free shuttle service to the Hamamatsucho Station, which was very convenient and ran almost every 1/2 hour. No problems during my 3 night stay, front desk help was very good with directions and suggestions.

review_body: Terrible ordeal , The hotel is rundown and poorly refurbished .I complained about the A/C , to be told that they will send Someone from housekeeping to have a look at the problem to which I replied what will housekeeping do and within a few minutes two young ladies arrived to check the room , Open inspection of the room and the air-conditioner they proceeded to tell me that all the rooms with the same even though they both repeatedly tried to hit the down button on the temperature and the up bottom on the fan . I then requested that engineering come and take a look and they sent someone from engineering who then remove the very very very dirty filter grate that allows air intake into the air-conditioner he took out a vacuum and proceeded to clean it .I then thought the problem would be solved I lay awake The whole night unable to sleep because the room was so hot there wasn’t even a bottle of water in the room or even a mini bar in the room to be able to have something to drink , eventually at about 6 AM once the weather has cooled down I manage to fall asleep I was then awoken rudely at 11:20 AM to be told that check out time is 11 AM I then said okay I will be out by 12 to Be told there will be an extra charge for the room if I need to take that long .On check asked for the manager and the front lady said what’s wrong and I told her and she said sorry, I highly recommend for people never to stay at this hotel

I stayed at the Tokyo Prince Hotel in July 2017 for 4 nights. I hold no status with the chain but was given the opportunity to sign up for the Seibu Emi Club upon making my online reservation.I was very impressed with my stay. My room overlooked Tokyo Tower and was generously sized by Tokyo standards. The hotel was also running a promotion where free breakfast was offered to Emi Club members (free to register). I found the breakfast spread to be varied and extensive. Bus transportation is provided to the Daimon/Hamamatsucho station every 30 minutes but the walk to Onarimon station is barely 2 minutes and is more convenient. The staff was especially helpful. The concierge team, specifically Ms. Rosalind and Mr. Moriya, provided great assistance with restaurant reservations and coordinated efficiently with my Citi Concierge to ensure everything was prepared. They were helpful throughout my stay and went the extra mile to wish me well upon my departure.I will not hesitate to stay at the Tokyo Prince again. I found great value during my stay. The upgraded lobby was also very pleasant.

I just like to write a little review about the Tokyo Price Hotel pool.If you are not staying at the hotel the entrance for an adult is now ¥8.000 all day .¥5.000 children from 4 years ~ 11 years all day There's a kids pool available. Unlike the public Shiba Koen pool u can use sun protection, toddlers under the age of 4 years can enter.You do need to cover up Tattoos with an plaster . Chairs are charged separately but you can use tables and seats for free. You can bring your own food into the pool area and eat with children in the garden area .

Great room with super king bed. Very reasonable price compared to the second Tokyo hotel we stayed at. They offer a ¥500 voucher per day for not having the room made up - good for the hip pocket and the environment. No room service but some OK places nearby, a Lawson convenience store in the basement and decent coffee in the room. The fresh baguette at the French cafe at the end of the driveway - bought with said ¥500 voucher - was excellent.

The Hotel staff was very friendly and helpful. This hotel offers an amazing view of the Tokyo Tower. The buffet is excellent with many delicious choices. Very convenient to public transportation (Subway right next to hotel entrance). There's a mini mart in the basement level of the hotel that closes at midnight. Excellent bathroom amenities and very comfortable beds. Coffee maker with complementary coffee and tea and a mini fridge. Free decent Wi-Fi. The bathroom is a bit outdated, but still works with great water pressure. I traveled in June and the pool was closed, check with hotel to see when it opens if it's something that you're interested in using. The hotel did allow us to check in an hour before regular check-in time, but only if the room is available. They do offer baggage holding while you wait and complementary umbrellas. There is a shuttle service that takes you to the nearby train station to take the monorail to the airport (Haneda) Unfortunately do not expect the shuttle driver to assist you with your baggage and you will have to carry your own bags up the stairs of the bus, as for unknown reasons they do not use the storage compartments on the side of the bus. If you're physically unable you should consider taking it Uber or a taxi which should be very inexpensive as the train station is very close. Overall I do recommend this hotel. Happy and safe travels.

This is a well run hotel with competent staff (not particularly friendly - more like professional). The room we had had a wonderful view of the Tokyo tower and the hotel is an easy walk to the Tokyo metro station Onarimon. There is a pretty good breakfast and the rooms are clean and just big enough. It is a good place and for us it was good value for money. However there are not a lot of restos within an easy walk of the hotel- and it would have been better if the staff were a little less stiff. I am still coming to terms with the 4000yen fee per person to use the pool- to my mind this is a silly way to try and make money.

It is very complicated to rate this hotel because it has very good aspects like the location ( near subway), a fantastic terrasse with view on the "Eiffel tower ", a nice breakfast room with a very decent breakfast even for a westerner, a swimming pool, rooms really bigger than anywhere else but in Japan: you can open your luggage and put clothes in a cupboard / drawers.But: you have to pay to go to the swimming pool and it closes at 17h: so complete non sense after a day visit, you have to pay a full day for one hour , it cost us as much as the room,for a family of three. The fantastic terrace closes unfortunately at 9 o'clock in the evening which is simply ridiculous for a last drink. We tried' the Chinese restaurant and were definitely punished for Eating Chinese in Japan : it was our worst meal after two weeks in the country: we did not get what we ordered the dumpling were full of water, no rice, wine outrageously expensive and not fantastic, pork lost in an ocean of tofu and got only the skin of the duck while we wanted the duck as mentioned in the menu, that is roasted, crêpes were thick and cold. We have eaten duck in China , it was fantastic, we only got the skin in Malaysia and here in Tokyo.

This hotel is right next to Tokyo Tower, Zojo-ji Temple and Shiba Park. There are two underground stations i walking distance. For breakfast we preferred Le Pain Quotidien which was also just next to the hotel. The rooms were renovated so there were enough power outlets to charge everybody' s gadgets. In summary the hotel met all our expectations for our stay in Tokyo.

Like most Japanese hotels, the service is great at the Tokyo Prince Hotel. We had a few miscommunications with the hotel regarding requesting/paying for an extra bed and it not being installed the first night we stayed. The concierge sent us Japanese fans as a sign of apology which was a nice touch. The hotel has gone through renovation and the front lobby is very beautifully done. The rooms are unfortunately still quite old and VERY small even for Japanese standards, although the view of Tokyo tower is quite breathtaking and a nice scene to come back to after a long day. There isn't much else to do around the hotel itself but most places are a short train/cab ride away - and hotel is convenient for the airport shuttles, both from Haneda and Narita.

I was very happy with my choice of hotels in Tokyo. I was worried about the size for the room and bed when looking for a room and this hotel was perfect. The bed I got ws a king size bed that was comfortable and had nice bedding. The room was large with a sitting area and table. This was nice because I was able to have my friends come over far a drink at the end of the night. The water pressure in the shower was good. House keeping was perfect also. They changed all my bedding every day and kept the room looking sharp. It was completed by the time I got back every day. The staff was better than any I have encountered in years. I don't have a complaint about anything. The location is central Tokyo, close to everything. There are two major sites right next to the hotel. If I return to Tokyo again, I will be staying here.

Adjacent to the grounds of the Zojo-ji Temple and Shiba Park, the Prince Tokyo provides peaceful serenity with the convenience of being in the heart of the city. Taxis are ever present at the lobby, and the Onarimon Station (Mita Line) is a 4 minute walk, Daimon Station (Asakusa Line and and Oedo Line) 10 minute walk, and Hamamatsucho Station JR 13 minute walk. Being in the midst of greenery, the nearest restaurants and Tokyo Tower are a 5 minute walk, but mitigated with a Lawsons in the basement.Service throughout was impeccable. Staff were professional and caring from the moment you step foot in the door.Common areas were elegant and well maintained. Rooms were clean and of western size, much larger than typical Japanese hotels, albeit a bit drab in color and feel.The breakfast buffet was top notch, the best I have experienced in Tokyo, with a huge selection of Japanese and western choices, all beautifully presented with an attention to detail. The dining room was large and felt spacious and provided personal space, even during its busiest hours. The view overlooked greenery and an outdoor dining area.Having stayed at dozens of hotels in Tokyo, this would be one of my favorites, with the only slight issue being a bit away from a JR station. I would definitely stay here again for either business or personal stays.

Stayed 3 nights on 10th floor in a room right face to the Tokyo Tower. The view is amazing and it is the closest I ever stayed to Tokyo tower. I stayed in 2 different Prince hotels in Tokyo but this is just by your window. And this is certainly the highlight of the 3 night stay.Check in was very efficient. I arrived quite late at around 10pm -- took the last shuttle bus from the metro station. Apart from that, I could remember one young lady from the reception who very kindly showed me the way to get to the back side, from that gate you can reach the tower in 2 minutes. However I don't recall other staff being attentive, the cleaning staff made my room once in my 3 night stay, and I could see she/he was doing it indifferently. The room itself -- by Tokyo standard, the size is OK. They recently renovated rooms but it looks like the bath room was excluded, especially the bath tub looks years old. And I don't mind saving water but you should let your guests use it anyway. I didn't like the tap. Another nightlight, there is a nestle coffee maker in the room. Disappointment: no gym, and a swimming pool that even as a guest you have to pay for admission.

Just next door to Tokyo tower, one of the best hotels I've stayed in during my both visits.Huge rooms, supper clean the staff are amazing and you can find everything you need in this hotel, supermarket, restaurants just all in.Recommend this hotel for short and long stay.

This hotel large size near Tokyo Tower is best location you see view Tokyo Tower Beautiful in night, Near JR Station & Metro and downstairs floor have Lawson in side room with full facilities. TV, Minibar, Bath Room, Internet Wifi.

This was a very nice hotel w modern amenities n good walking distance to the subway as well as store in the Ikebukuro area. We had two twin beds n altho there weren't any closets or dresser, we made due n love the modern bathroom. The hotel is attached to a huge shopping plaza n we even got to see a teen pop group singing on the stage. We went with a tour n we had a breakfast buffet daily which was awesome-great selections n even a latte machine. Would definitely stay there again. Also I was glad they had 3 prong outlets for my flat iron n they also had a nice pitcher that made hot water..oh did miss having an ice machine--had to run down to a very close Family mart there in the hotel--loved that shop because they had good snacks n sold cubed ice in sealed cups..pastries n snacks were very good.

Want to watch Sakura cherry blossom from the lap of luxury- you have come to the right place. I have been visiting this hotel since 30 years, when I first came to tokyo for business. But never got a chance to stay here. We had made up our mind to stay here during our last trip and sure enough enjoyed every minute of it.Got a nice deal through Booking.com for a standard room. But while checking in found there was a mix-up, so the staffs decided to upgrade us to suite. The hotel itself is out of the history book, reeking nostalgic feelings at all corners. The suite was furnished in wooden panellings and bathrooms in french sanitary ware. Only regret was the TV had channels of only Documentary and News channels in Japanese and there were no International channels at all.Right next door was the Jozi Buddhist Temple in its sprawling grounds filled with cherry blossom Sakura flowers. In the background was the grand old Tokyo Tower, now left obsolete because the new SkyTree has come up to take up the broadcasting of Tele-communications, but the beauty of Tokyo Tower remains unbeaten.There is not enough words to explain the overwhelming hospitality of Japanese and the hotel staffs. Very courteous and obliging, to extent of making us feel embarrassed. Breakfast in the Coffee shop overlooking the Tokyo Tower and the greenery around it, was out of this world, especially to find this expanse of greenery all around the hotel, in the midst of this megapolis.

I am currently staying at the Tokyo Prince. The Standard Club room is nicely planned out, small but not by Tokyo standards - in fact lager than normal. The lobby area has been remodeled and so everything is bright and fresh and it is located next to some lovely green spaces , temple and Tokyo Tower.But beware when your purchase from through Travelocity as advertised on TripAdvisor.. They told me that breakfast was included but it turned out to NOT be the hotel buffet breakfast. Rather it is only a pathetic breakfast similar to airline food laid out on a room that reminds you of a lower grade airline lounge at the airport. Windowless room with no character and poor quality food. While my reservation said "breakfast included" and I was assured by the booking agent that it was the regular hotel breakfast (which costs 2500 yen when not included in the room rate) this turned out not to be the case. Very disappointing and definitely not worth the extra cost of booking a "Club" room.

One of the bigger rooms I've stayed in, in Japan. They had just completed a renovation so the lobby is very beautiful and rooms are nice. Is very close to the Metro and the JR lines. The lack of a gym and pool are the only things that hold this place back from being amazing.

The room space is the bigest l have ever lived in Tokyo. The location is also pretty good, if you want to Tokyo tower or run around the park. Although it isn't near the subway station,but you can take its shuttle bus to hamama Hamamatsuchō station connected your nexr trip. There are several restaurants and one drug store near Diamond station.

The hotel is located in ideal location which is close to the beautiful temple (early morning walk would be great) and great view to Tokyo Tower from room. However, it's quite far from the nearest station, let say 15-20 mins walk.Service is great as the Japanese is good at satisfying their customers. Highly recommend!!
