Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam

review_body: Great location right underneath Tokyo Tower. There is a temple next door, subway stations nearby, and a great street to wonder down and sample the food. Well layed out breakfast, and the staff were great. There is a swimming pool, but we did not get to try it out.

Stayed 4 nights for business. Positives: 1) Quiet - Hotel amidst vast, serene and green surrounds, rare in a major city. 2) Convenient - nearest metro 2 min walk away3) Clean - While room setting is not most modern, room is clean and comfortable Less Good:1) Tired breakfast menu - While they have non Japanese breakfast items, these were the same with tired selection after 2-3 days. Tip: Good to have room with view of Tokyo Tower - You think you are in Paris.

Hotel rooms are a bit dated, despite its modern architecture. Do pay more for a room on a higher floor facing the Tokyo Tower. It's worth it. Nice: rooms have a small balcony.Breakfast buffet is ridiculous expensive. JPY 3700 per person. A la carte, a coffee is JPY 1000 alone. The next Starbucks is 500m away using the rear exit near the gym.The gym is window-less room but modern equipment. They have a sauna with a built-in TV (but you can't change the channel) and a hot tub. It's OK if included in your rate, but don't pay extra.

It may not be near typical shopping districts like Shinjuku, but there are a few subway stations near the hotel which easily provide access, and the hotel is right outside Tokyo Tower, and some of the rooms provide a great, unobstructed view!Breakfast was wonderful! A huge spread of both Japanese and Western selections, including rice, soup, meat, eggs, cereal, juices, and dessert. There is an omelette station, and I really liked the plates they used.The hotel is a little dated (it turns 50 this year), but it is going to be closed until next year for renovations. We stayed about a week before it closed. Air conditioning is centrally controlled, and they have heating during winter/spring months, so it can get stuffy. But this is easily solved by opening the windows slightly to let some air in.

Location really feels secluded, and even bird calls from the park. Although Ravens song is not the best sounding.What is fascinating is that the Tokyo Prince withstood every imaginable modernizations.To achieve cult status required probably another 30 years, but I do not think décor does not pass.The rooms are showing clear signs of wear, and prices are no longer in line with what you pay for.

I stayed in this hotel for a week in February and I have to say that it is amazing! Yes it's old, but you know, once you're there is like you're totally feeling the Tokyo atmosphere. Although Tokyo might seem very modern, it also has a very typical architecture style that can be seen in this hotel. The beds are incredibly comfortable, I slept like a baby in those! The room also has a closet, a tv and free wifi. The bathroom is not big, but it's comfortable and the toilet has that thing with buttons on, totally japanese! I also had breakfast every morning at their restaurant on the 3rd floor - this restaurant is amazing and the food is delicious! Another great thing about this hotel is that it is super well located between the Tokyo Tower and the Shiba Park, and also next to the Zojo-ji Temple. If you walk a couple of blocks away, you'll find the Hamamatsucho Station to the Yamanote Line which basically takes you to the most popular districts in Tokyo.By the way, if you agree to not have your room cleaned for the time of your stay, you get a 500 yen coupon to trade in their Lawson Shop down in the hotel's arcade.

This hotel has a very large and presentable foyer but the driveway and surrounding buildings are typical 1980's concrete and plastic. Well worn and a little shabby. When you enter the hotel you get a sense of space but also a slightly tired and worn out feel. That said, my room over looked the Tower which was an amazing view. The room was small'ish buy this is very typical of Tokyo hotels. The Green scheme is good offering JPY500 for each day you don't use the room cleaning service. You can spend the vouchers in the Lawson store downstairs.The room rates varied by day but over my 7 day stay it averaged at less than £100 and with the current strong yen that wasn't too bad.Good location for the Tower and Hamarikyu Gardens. Easy walk to Hamamachio station and the monorail to Haneda (10 mins walk). There is also a large temple right next door.In conclusion I would say this is a typical large Tokyo hotel which is good for both business and leisure. Reasonably priced and well located.

After making a mistake while purchasing the hotel... we ended up at Tokyo Prince Hotel.The hotel is OLD... but I'm sure they know it. The hotel will be closed this year for a renovation (well deserved).The baby cot was not there when we arrived. But was done in the following day.Staff very helpful but not all could speak English (comum in Japan I guess..)Location is great. Just 3 min from Tokyo tower and a huge temple just next door.Yamato Line station is relatively near (10mn walking).The convenience store inside the hotel is a plus. Good price and good food. Awesome if you want to sabe bit with food.Hope to get the chance to stay there again after the renovation.

My husband purchased a gate1 travel package and this hotel was included. It was an amazing experience. The staff was polite and very helpful especially since our Japanese was limited. I had ordered a portable wifi gadget to assist with our travel and it arrived at the hotel and given to me as we checked in. The breakfast every morning delicious and a great start to our days. My husband especially liked their array of pasties with his coffee. The location is close to bus stations and the railway. If you're lucky, the hotel view could be facing Tokyo Tower. Highly recommend.

We done two stays at the Tokyo Prince Hotel during our trip to Japan and both stays were wonderful. Make sure to ask for the rooms facing the Tokyo Tower as they have magnificent views both during the day and at night. You won't get lost making your way back to the hotel as you just have to look out for the tower. The Hotel is quite dated but clean, Yummy Buffet breakfast and Dinner at Porto restaurant. Staff are friendly and some of them speak a bit of English.Lawsons minimart is located in the basement as well as a mini shopping arcade. They have a smokers room with cigarettes in a vending machine if you are in need for a cigarette a midnight. There is no gym however, you can take a 7minute stroll to the Prince Park Tower Hotel to use there gymnasium and charge back to your room- it's a bit pricey but if you really want to work out then it's well worth it. Rooms are great and comfortable, Wifi is fast, bathrooms are clean. I will definitely stay at the Tokyo Prince hotel again.

We were on a family holiday with 2 teenage boys and had specifically requested one twin room for them. My travel agent had been diligent and had sent (and forwarded copies to me) of 3 emails confirming that we'd have one twin room. When we arrived we had to queue for 30 minutes to check in. They denied having seen our room requests - despite having replied to the emails. We then spent a further 30 minutes waiting to get one room and were told they would come back to us in an hour with details of the second room. That actually took 3 hours although they did manage to get this room on the same floor at least. The hotel is very large and pretty much what you'd expect room-wise. The bathrooms were nice.However, our biggest disappointment is that the boys were unable to use the swimming pool. They are both competent swimmers (seriously- you could be swimming in the Olympics and you still wouldn't be allowed in the pool). They also have a 'no tattoo' rule - i.e. if you have one, you can't use the pool. I guess that is to prevent Yakuza from using the pool and none us are tattooed, but you should be aware of this.Food in the hotel hideously expensive. If you do find yourself with a Tokyo Tower facing room, then the view is very nice. It's not a great spot otherwise although a short taxi ride to many other going out spots.All in all, our experience let down by the fact that our boys couldn't use the gym or pool and the ridiculously long check in experience.

We arrived in Tokyo early and tried to get early check in unfortunately only room was smoking but they got us into a room as early as possibleWe had a suite which was two joined rooms but it worked well Furnishings a bit tired but was very clean it needs a refurbishment badly Great breakfast Helpful staffGreat location for exploring city

We traveled to Tokyo with family and we were happy about the convenient hotel location, directly next to Tokyo Tower. Nice hotel with very friendly staff. Breakfast was a lot of choice and in summer you can sit outside like in a nice garden. Not far away from the Metro station. With Taxi to Ginza just under 10 minutes.

You can't really top this hotel's location. Smack dab in front of Tokyo Tower and within walking distance of numerous subways and JR lines, it's probably one of the best locations of places I've ever stayed at. In addition, it's literally next door to a massive Buddhist temple, which made for some pretty epic photo opportunities and cultural experiences.As we never actually ended up eating at this hotel, I cannot speak for its offerings in the food department. However, there's a convenience store literally in the basement, not to mention multiple Family Mart's just across the street. We also thoroughly enjoyed Le Pain Quotidient, which was located just outside of the hotel. Reception and bell desk staff were extremely professional and kind. Really appreciated, especially after a long flight.However... my room was designated non-smoking and as soon as I walked in, I was greeted with an overwhelming smell of cigarettes. I couldn't quite tell if it was from down the hallway or in my actual room, but needless to say, it drove my sinuses batty. I was also not too happy with my pillows, as they were flat as pancakes and made me extremely dizzy.

This was my 1st stay at the Prince Hotel Tokyo on my 3rd trip to Tokyo, Japan for 3 nights, I wanted to be next door to the Zojoji Temple. This is an older Hotel with the very best Breakfast Buffet at Porto Restaurant, serving creative Western & Japanese food including a very refreshing Soba & Udon Bar with numerous condiments. The green tea rolls & black cherry sauce for my yogurt was heavenly & addicting. The dining room has floor to ceiling glass windows overlooking their rose & sculpture garden, including a view of the majestic Tokyo Tower. Our room was large, clean & comfortable, had robes, slippers, a teapot, green tea bags, a refrigerator & toiletries.I return to this city because of the Japanese warmth & hospitality. We were looking for "Hyoki", a Japanese Tatami-style private seating restaurant, but could not find it. We saw a woman pushing a baby's stroller and stopped to ask her. She said, "I will walk you there", she also went into the restaurant to make sure there was a table for us before leaving. I was straining my neck up the wall at Roppongi Station, to check the fare and how many train stops there were to Daimon Station. A Security Guard came up to me with a printed map, she wrote down everything I needed to know at the back. They take pride here to know that they are upholding their society by treating other people with great care, diligence and respect. They are brought up to feel a shared ownership, a great sense that we are all interconnected.Zojoji Temple, Jodo Shu Main Temple (Pure Land Sect) of Buddhism - Daimon Station. Jodo Shu preaches Senju Nembutsu (the single-minded recitation of the Nembutsu). By reciting the Nembutsu Prayer, "Namu-Amida-Butsu", all people can be equally accorded salvation. Thanks to Amida Buddha's benevolence that is meted out to all people without discrimination, enabling them to be reborn in Gokuraku-Jodo ( Pure Land of Bliss) after their death. This is the central Nembutsu Seminary for Priests and Novices. The Sunday 11.30am Buddhist Ceremony had over 100 Priests and Novices, lined up in the Main Hall on the right side of the image of Amida Buddha, in a very choreographic reverent & characteristic manner. They recited the Nembutsu Prayer accompanied by drums on the left, it was an ecstatic atmosphere. The congregation was invited to remove their shoes and led up to the Main Altar. We participated in the "Havan" (ritual of sprinkling sesame-like seeds & offering them into the consecrated fire), given pieces of white paper to place on our tongue, handed an elongated peacock feather to touch the feet of Amida Buddha. Removed the paper from our tongue and placed it in a basket. Accepted "Prasad" (sacred edible food, a religious offering) it was a piece of white & pink mochi and a personal hand towel with a written prayer, both elegantly wrapped. We attended the 5pm service every evening, they were very deeply respectful & remarkable. On the right side of the Temple is the Unborn Children Garden Cemetery, rows of stone statues of children representing unborn children, who have been miscarried, aborted and stillborn. Parents can choose a statue in the Garden Cemetery and decorate it with small clothing and toys. The statues are accompanied by a small gift for Jizo, The Guardian of Unborn Children, to ensure they are brought to the afterlife. Stones are piled by each statue, they are meant to shorten the amount of suffering, a child has to go through on the way to the afterlife.Zojoji Treasure Gallery - Daimon Station. On the first basement level of the Temple's Main Hall. An Exhibition titled "Kano Kazunobu's Five Hundred Arhats" showcases the titular Buddhist paintings by the late-Edo Period Painter Kano Kazunobu which are in the possession of Zojoji.Shibazakura Japanese Restaurant - A Japanese Tatami-style private seating restaurant serving a Fuji 8-course dinner at the Prince Park Tower, Tokyo on the other side of the Zojoji Temple. I stayed there on my last trip, it was totally sold out on this trip.Mori Art Museum - Roppongi Station. Located on the 53rd floor of the Mori Tower with fine views of the city from the Skywalk & Observatory Tower. Takashi Murakami: The 500 Arhats is a Solo Exhibition, Murakami's 100-meter-long painting, The 500 Arhats, is one of the largest paintings ever produced in Global Art History. "Maman" the bronze giant spider sculpture by Louise Bourgeois, is located in the courtyard of the Mori Tower. Kyu-Shiba-rikyu-Onshi-Gardens - Daimon Station. Designated as "A Place of Scenic Beauty". The pond is the central feature of the garden with two islets Nakajima & Ukishima.

The room I had was small and bare-walled (with the exception of one small print of France) and a long hike from the elevator. But it did have a pleasant view, tea-maker, adequate closet and hangers and a functioning digital alarm clock. Very small bathroom as well.I took advantage of the option of a 500-yen rebate for skipping maid service altogether one day, which helps the environment and kept the room rate remarkably low (it was a group conference rate, but still a bargain). More hotels should offer this choice,The staff was helpful and pointed out restaurant areas and sights nearby and made meticulous arrangements for storing luggage on day of departure, which was then primed for the airport bus.One big negative: the hotel charged half a full day's price for early arrival. Since the rate was low, and I was tired, I accepted this deal, but it is a rip-off. There was no shortage of empty rooms when I arrived at 10 am. I was staying 3 nights. Why not let guests who arrive early use the rooms rather than wait in the lobby, as several did, looking bored and resentful until 2 pm.

The best part of this hotel is the location - it is within walking distance of Tokyo Tower, and located right next to the 600-year-old Zozoji Shrine. We had a clean, large room for 2 people. There are kimonos for your use in the room. The subway stations (Daimon and Akabanebashi) are about a 10-15 min walk, and they have detailed maps at the reception desk. The bathrooms have the high-tech Japanese toilets with seat warmers and bidets. There is also a free wifi router in each room, which means that wifi is ultra fast and you can stream media to your devices.The breakfast buffet is excellent, with a huge choice of Japanese, Chinese, and European breakfast foods, both hot and cold. They also have an omelette station, and machines that make various kinds of coffee and tea drinks. They also had some fantastic cake! For breakfast! Yum! The breakfast buffet is also next to a beautiful garden, so if you get there early snag one of the seats by the big bay windows so you can look out at the garden and the Tokyo Tower. We also enjoyed Yakiniku Champion, one of the hotel's restaurants on the first floor. It's a Korean BBQ place with fantastic food and amazing service, reasonably priced.We will definitely stay here again if we return to Tokyo, and next time we will request a Tokyo Tower view room! What a great stay.

This place is a classic. Old school Japan; from a bygone era when they were trying to accommodate to a global standard, but were just a bit off in true Japanese fashion. Service is so kind and heartfelt, just about any small issues can be forgiven.Location is lovely for walking and some great restaurants nearby. Tokyo tower is right next door, and, as my title says: getting a Tower view makes a big difference.Don't bother with a breakfast-included plan. Buffet not very good; there's a good French(ish) cafe just out the front, across the parking lot and to the right before the entrance to the temple.Value for money is good for mid-range travelers to experience a bit of real Japan, warts and all. Business travelers might get annoyed because they aren't interested in stopping to smell the roses and enjoy the gritty details.Wifi very good. Free TV only has CNN for English.

We stayed at this hotel for 3 nights in April 2015, during our family trip to Tokyo. The hotel is huge, room is spacious enough for all of us (2 adults, 2 kids). Breakfast was decent. There's a small convenient store at the basement area. It's a 5 minutes walk to the nearest metro station. Tokyo Tower is also a short walk from this hotel. Hard Rock Cafe Tokyo is a 20 minutes walk from this hotel (quite an uphill distance, but it was a lovely walk as the weather was mild at the time).

I am trying to keep in mind that this is a 3-star hotel and that my expectations should be appropriate... Having said that, I had a great deal of trouble checking in and getting a non-smoking room, mainly due to the fact that the front-desk clerk's English was very poor and he was very reluctant to ask for help. I happen to be in Japan while the outside temperatures averaged low 70s in November. The hotel's HVAC system had already been converted to heat mode and it was not possible to turn on the air conditioning. While low 70s may not sound like it necessarily warrants A/C, being on the 10th floor, combined with humidity outside made it very uncomfortable. The hotel also had no fans - their answer to the temperature issue was "open the window!"Everything else was okay. The hotel itself is old, very outdated and in dire need of renovation. The staff meant well, but I think there are probably better places to stay at about the same price.One very bright point was the convenience store on the basement level of the hotel. It was very very convenient to have a place to grab water, quick snacks, etc.

The staff was very friendly, but the décor is dated; as the halls have a musty odor. Our room was clean and we had a view to the Tokyo Tower. There s a grocery store on the lower level, which was very convenient.The location is good and there is a shuttle bus to the subway/train station.

That is probably the worst hotel I staid in the past 10 years. They charge 350€ for a room which is more than basic. The carpets across the whole floor a dirty, the room stinked. The room and technology is from the 80th. The Wifi did not work. My colleagues had exactly the same. No minibar, You need to see a supermarket to get a bottle of water. Cup of coffee is at 9€. It was like an emerging country two star hotel - don't try.

Best part about Tokyo Prince is that there is a little store for buying food after hours. We arrived at midnight so we're delighted to get some food. It is not in a busy district and some walk to the nearest train station and shops, but next to a lovely temple and Fantastic views of Tokyo Tower. It is an older hotel which needs refurbishment but it's very clean with helpful staff. The free shuttle bus was handy as well.

We stayed at the hotel for 5 nights. I really enjoyed this place: very clean (thought a bit outdated - 1960th), great location - 3 subway stations within a mins, friendly staff. Rooms are a bit small, but we had much smaller rooms in some hotels in Europe.Breakfast had a lot of choices - Japanese and continental.. Wifi worked perfect, so no complains. And of course wonderful view on Tokyo Tower from our window. That alone cost a lot!Would highly recommend this hotel for a budget travelers.

One of the best hotels you will ever stayIt is completely perfect Only price is high But it's the prince hotelWifi excellent Rooms perfect Location amazing Staff very professional One of the bestIf you are in Tokyo You must stay at....,,.,,,,

This hotel was built in 1964, just before the Tokyo Olympic, as the landmark hotel of the Seibu Prince Hotel group. Thus, the rooms are old, but still clean. The staff are very helpful and polite. Great location near Tokyo Tower and in front of Zojyoji Temple. It has become an average affordable hotel now.

Rooms are a bit small, hotel offers no room-service at all, breakfast is average and there is no gym.On a more positive node the wireless internet was free, fast and reliable - the hotel is located very close to Tokyo Tower and a metro-station, plus there is a small convenience store at hotel lower level. Staff is also very helpful and friendly, but from my experience that's standard at Japanese hotels.Quite a few nearby restaurants is also a plus.

We arrived here three days ago. We are very happy with the size of the room, cleanliness, location and the staff. We are just by the Tokyo tower, train and subway station etc. There are several good restaurants to pick from if you do not want to venture outside.

Great location. The rooms were old but very clean and charming. We loved it. Stuff is beyond expectations. Very helpful and polite. Great location. Many restaurants in 15 min range walk. Highly recommended. We had 3 months old baby with us and he loved to sleep in the middle of king bed. We were staying in the room #430

"Seen better days" is the first phrase that comes in mind. The Tokyo Prince Hotel seems like it used to be a truly excellent 5 star hotel, which slowly degraded to 3/4 star territory. The good news is that this means that the rooms are very big by Tokyo standards. The bad news is that the bathroom, furniture and other equipment is visibly old. I gladly took this trade-off, as I truly enjoy being able to open my suitcase without stepping into the bathroom.The staff spoke fairly decent English, but they were fairly overloaded so they couldn't always be as helpful as they would have preferred to be. The reservation system was a bit funky, as the smoking and non-smoking rooms are not reserved separately, but instead your preference is recorded separately as a "best effort" comment. This would explain why other reviewers ended up in smoking rooms despite their preference.The air conditioner worked very well and was unusually quiet, which is important in the Japanese summer. The smallish LCD TV had the standard Japanese channels, but no foreign broadcasts. The bed was big and comfy. There were individual mini wifi-routers for the rooms, which helped keep the wifi link uncongested. The only real problem I had with the room equipment was that the mini-fridge emitted an incredibly loud and sharp screeching noise, even by mini-fridge standards. There was a sign on the fridge saying that if the noise bothers you, you should turn the fridge off. I took their advice but was left without convenient access to cold beverages. Fortunately there are vending machines on several floors, and there is a fully stocked convenience store right on the basement floor of the Hotel.The Hotel is located in the garden of the Zojo-ji, a very pretty Buddhist temple with a nicely groomed park surrounding it (it is especially beautiful in cherry-blossom season). Too bad the area in front of the hotel was converted to a huge parking lot instead of leaving it as a park. There are indoor and outdoor restaurants on the premises, and the eateries of the Hamamatsucho-area are also within the reach of an 8 minute walk.The nearest train station is the Onarimon subway station on the Toei Mita line (so getting to the Imperial Palace and Tokyo station is no problem). To access the JR Yamanote line or the Tokyo Monorail, a 10 minute walk is necessary to Hamamatsucho station.

Tokyo Prince Hotel is the hotel with the high formality. A famous Buddhist temple "Zojo-ji" is next to the hotel. It would be better to stroll through you in a morning and nightfall here.Tokyo Tower is seen from a window of the hotel. The equipment in a hotel is a little old.

An excellent hotel. do visit it, staff is very humble with few english speaking staff and very helpful.Its chinese restaurent is also good. we made special request of rice with chinken and veggies ,no fish and no pork and they made it everytime we asked for. Very near to tokyo tower, hotel backside is a dew steps away from tokyo tower.

The hotel is centrally located. It has a swimmingpool where they charge you 50 $ per person even if you stay at the hotel. We had booked non-smoking rooms but received rooms that smelled like an ashtray. When we complained the staff and even the manager was unhelpful. Finally after lots of dicussions we got a non-smoking room. However, many corridors stink of smoke and I would not recommend an astmatic to stay there. The hotel needs a renovation. It is quite wore down.

Service was excellent from checkin to housekeeping to breakfast. Walkable distance to JR and subway stops. Easy walk to many sites. Tokyo Tower was right next door, so it was our guidepost to find "home". Our only disappointment was with the room air conditioning. It kept the temperature at 25C but didn't dehumidify, so it was moist. It would be a good idea to bring a small fan to create some air movement while you sleep.

The hotel is located a short walk from a few train lines so it is convenient to get around Tokyo without a car. They also have a complimentary shuttle service to the JR station. It is next to the temple, Tokyo tower, and a short walk to some of the best alleyway eateries!The hotel itself is nice and clean. The rooms have a great view of the city.

This hotel is very good, why because it's rooms has a view of the Tokyo Tower. Very good at night!! Beautiful and Elegant. Also very convenient and a very short trip to the Tokyo tower. I really enjoyed my experience in this wonderful hotel.. Enjoy yourself!

I was in Tokyo recently for a short business visit and stayed at the Tokyo Prince Hotel mainly due to its proximity to my place of work. However, I was pleasantly surprised at the high quality service and very well kept rooms at relatively low cost on offer. As noted by other reviewers, the hotel decor is a little dated but the interiors have been very well maintained and the close proximity to the Zojo-ji temple and other shopping attractions was a bonus. Also, the Airport Limousine service from Narita and Haneda make a stop at the hotel which was most convenient.

We were on a 17 day trip to Asia, and the first three days were in Japan (the rest in China). The Tokyo Prince is across the street from the Tokyo tower, inspired by the Eiffel Tower. Lit up at night with many colors, we asked for a room with a direct view of it. Coming back to Tokyo at night one day, we found having a 1000 foot high Christmas tree like structure to guide us allowed us to find our hotel. Anyway, the food and personal service in the restaurant was excellent, the food varied, fresh and exotic. The room was okay, but lets discuss something not normally discussed in a review; the toilet! The seat was electronically warmed as was the built in Bidet. We all have to use a toilet, and nowhere is this a better experience than in Japan! Rugs and furnishings could use replacement, but that was a minor detail. Only complaint was no Wifi, they said the computer was too old. The over all service and ambiance was great. I recommend it.

This hotel is huge, it is a litle oldfashioned due to it was inagurated for Olympic games in 1964. I really enjoyed this place because it is within walking distance from 2 subway stations, so, you can reach almost any place in a really short period of time.I think If somebody is thinking in visiting Japan this hotel sounds like an option to consider. The service is ok and the food for breakfast is a nice and assorted. If you don´t want to try Japanesse food, you can choose among more occidental options.

This was a world class hotel, that has gotten a little tired. Location is great, service is top shelf and breakfast buffet is memorable in quality and quantity. To be sure, ask for what you need and the hotel will bend over backward to help no matter the staffs' department. This is a big hotel and the rooms are relatively small, there is a lot of bureaucracy so try to upgrade your room with different management shifts, if you fail the 1st time.

Great hotel. Close to all transportation. No English speaking channels except for cnn that had japeness in the background. This is Japan not the U.S. Or England. Who cares about TV Tokyo has so much to do that you will barely be in the room.

Very good experience at this hotel.mreceived a room with the Tokyo Tower in the background. Location was perfect to take the Train to any part ofTokyo. Service was fast. Breakfast was huge amount of food.

Old Hotel building at a very convenient location. i am surprise to see the large size rooms as i believe in Tokyo the real estate cost is highest in the world. As per Japanese culture very courteous staff. Pickup point for most of the site seeing buses.

Tokyo Prince Hotel is a good choice for those looking for a longer stay. Its set next to Tokyo tower and near to subway stations. The breakfast selection is good; really like the croissants and chipolata sausages. I was there for work and late night its not difficult to find hot meals at budget restaurants nearby.

Tokyo Prince Hotel wasn’t a bad choice. It was quite convenient – about a 5-min walk to Onarimon station. The hotel is quite old – the lobby was not bad but our room (so I assume other rooms as well) was quite out of date. Our room had a smell to it – I’m not sure if it was due to the fact that it was a smoking room but I’m pretty sure it was not a smoke smell. It was more like a soggy/humid kind of smell mixed with cigarette smell. Our room was SMALL – we were running out of luggage space! Two guests, four luggage, and a bunch of shopping bags. We had no room to walk without tripping over our bags. Our room had quite the view! Right outside our window was the Tokyo Tower. It was a nice way to see the tower without having to walk over to the tower. So, asking for a tower-facing room would be your best bet if you have no intention of going to the Tokyo Tower.The staff was extremely friendly – from the moment we checked-in to our departure, the staff was friendly and helpful.Although they were not super fluent at English, after a few attempts in re-phrasing our concern/inquiry, they were able to assist us and provide us with answers. Lastly, there is a Lawson’s (I believe?) at the basement of this hotel which is opened until midnight. Super convenient for a late night snack because there is not much around the area.I would recommend this hotel for the view, the staff, and the convenience to the metro station. It was worth the price!

i could see tokyo tower from my room. the room rate was quite reasonable at around 11k yen per night for twin room, and for the view. it looks like a business hotel with lots of conferences and business man.i had to stay there one night and they kept telling me there's no room, until i managed to book online, and waited another 15minutes before it reached their reservation system.the room is really very old. there was no coffee.i hated the business center, as it requires you to generate password on the PC, key in password at the printer, by the time it took up all the paid time on the PC. the whole thing is faulty and bugged, and it doesn't give you any change. i don't know how many dollars i spent on printing 1 air ticket.. one of the service crew scolded me when i told him about the process flaw and lack of coin change. I didn't know what was wrong with that man.there is no coin laundry in the hotel. there was a kind staff who showed me how to get to the nearest coin laundry. by the time i reached, the coin laundry was full and it was quiet at late night. for safety reasons i took a cab back.

Stayed at the Tokyo Prince for 4 nights and was extremely unimpressed. The Hotel was old, dirty under the bed and the room smelled like my moms old wet shoes. I also couldn't locate any English channels on the TV. I had mixed feeling for the staff at the concierge desk...I had a few great people i spoke with and a few that seemed irritated that I would ask question about directions or tourist sites (hmmmmm......).I will say that the room rate was reasonable and the hotel was in a great location for easily accessing the subway or JR train line to many top tourist sites. They also have a free shuttle to the main train station which was helpful.

Last week I stayed at the Tokyo Prince Hotel in Tokyo. I have to say this hotel is very shabby and not so nice as I expected it to be. The Staff were not so friendly as I would have expected in a Tokyo hotel. The rooms were old and had stains on the carpets.The breakfast feast like it had been sitting around for some time and the bar in the hotel had also some not so polite staff.It felt to me like they did not like to have us stay at this hotel.I do not recommend this hotel at all, there are better hotels in Tokyo.

The Tokyo Prince Hotel is a value hotel right next to the Tokyo Tower. It has a bus connection to Narita airport and is well connected with the subway system. The restaurants are underwhelming and often closed for a late dinner. There are no restaurants in immediate vicinity. However, the rooms are big for Tokyo standards and provide a comfortable stay. You must request non-smoking rooms and even then my room had a bad cold smoke odor. I skipped the breakfast in the hotel and opted for visiting a great organic bakery and restaurant just 200m outside the hotel. Ask the staff for directions, it's very easy. For me breakfast is very important before I head out to business meetings. Having this alternative makes the Tokyo Prince a better location.

I have mixed feelings about this hotel. Most of my negative feelings are probably from a lack of understanding, or a failure on my part to fully read and understand various options the hotel has to offer. First off, the good:This hotel is in a really nice quiet location. It has semi-quick access to 4 different stations:Onarimon (Subway)Hamamatucho (Monorail, Trains)Daimon (Subway)Kamiyacho (Subway)The area is very quiet, almost too quiet. But if you want to feel like you are not in the city, this area is great for that. There are a few temples near by, one of which is right next door. The Zojo-ji temple. You also have very close access to the Tokyo Tower (not to be confused with the Tokyo Skytree). This place is an easy 10 minute or less walk from the hotel. The room was quite spacious, and had a decent TV, Chairs, large bed (King for us), and a nice view. We were on the 10th floor so we could see quite a distance.There was a convenience store in the basement level of the hotel. This was by far the most money saving option we had as far as food. Not only that, but the service was fantastic. Speaking of service. The hotel staff is very friendly. They are quick to help you, and find someone who can speak English if they are not familiar. I was very happy with their service. Now for the not so good:Laundry service. If you absolutely must have the hotel do laundry, be prepare to pay big bucks. I misread the paper, and thought our bill was going to be about 3,000 Yen (or about 30.00). Nope, not even close. It turned out to be 13,000 Yen! Or roughly 115.00 USD! This was for 2 very small bags of cloths. Needless to say, I wasn't happy at all with this. I attempted to speak to the laundry manager, but they said the price was fixed.Restaurants = Expensive! Talk about over priced. I'm not talking just a little bit, I'm taking 2 meals were 75.00 USD! Not only that, but the food quality was not the best. We ate at the Shimizu Japanese restaurant for some sushi. Some of the sushi was good, but I've had better in the states, which was quite disappointing. Also, unless you are willing to pay out the wazoo for breakfast at their buffet, don't bother. It was "okay", but I ended up preferring to get food from the in house convenience store on the basement level. Mixed Feelings:The bed. The bed was as hard as a stone slab, but quite honestly, we got a good night sleep on it. Just don't lay for too long, or your back will end up a rock itself. The AC in the room wasn't very cold (perhaps I'm just used to colder air). The staff was really nice, and brought up a floor fan to help cool off the room. Final Thoughts:Would I visit this hotel again? Maybe (if there were no better options).Would I find a hotel in the surrounding area? Yes.Would I ever eat at the hotel restaurants again? No.Would I recommend to others? Yes, but only without warnings on the *extra costs* that might sneak up on you.

We stayed here for 4 nights and were more than happy with this hotel. After a small booking issue on check-in, everything went smoothly. Although a little faded, this hotel has everything a tourist needs. Metro and rail was very close, breakfast more than adequate, and the room very spacious, with bathtub, free wifi, a huge king bed, a safe,fridge, and many toiletries. There was a convenience store in the basement, and the choice of several restaurants. A French bakery, offering gourmet sandwiches was just outside the front gate. The Tokyo metro was the best I've seen in the world- and I've travelled extensively. I'm not that fond of cities, but we had a fabulous time in Tokyo!

Pro's: * Great location right near Tokyo Tower* Close to Roppongi & also the Tokyo Metro line is a few minutes walk* Helpful staff, clean hotel* Restaurants, Bar, Lawson Supermarket, etc., within premisesCon's:* Paradise for 70's decor fans* Very dated furnishings, carpets, etc* Smell of cigarette smoke every whereComment: Wouldn't hesitate for a short stay here again

Excellent room for a family of three. Two larger queen size beds n a single bed for childrens. Spacious room with shower and bath tub. Separate toilet. Hotel staff are very friendly and helpful. Airport transport available in front of the hotel. Easy access to subways and food outlets. Near to FamilyMart similar to 7-11. Close to Tokyo Tower and Zojoji Temple.

We really enjoyed our three nights here (upgraded to a suite). It was well positioned out of the hustle of some of the more well known tourist spots. While the down side is that the decor is rather dated (but clean), it has a "big hotel" post war charm which works well.

The hotel has small rooms, is not new, but its clean and confortable enough, the quality-price os great for a city like Tokyo. As in many cases, people in the hotel barely speak english but always try to be helpful. The hotel is next to a beautiful Buddhist temple and a few block away from the Hamamatsucho Station from where you can get to any where.I loved breakfast which has enough occidental food and also a good selection of Japanese.On the way to the Station you'll find good noodle places a good price.

Hotel provides free WiFi. The facilities were old. Room was spacious. It has free shuttle bus to Hamamatsucho Station. There was no complimentary bottle water.Going Tokyo Tower is a few minutes walk. You can get to their subway (Daimon and Orinamon) within 10min walk.

The Tokyo Prince is a very good hotel.The location is excellent and close to Roppongi.The rooms are clean and comfortable and the hotel has excellent restaurants.The staff is very friendly and helpful.

We love this hotel, worth the many weeks I spent choosing where to stay in Tokyo. I did take into consideration the location, ( I love that it is next to a tranquil park and many dining options), buffet breekkie included in the stay- we stayed her 9 nights ans used it as base for exploring Tokyo and Mt. Fuji/Hakone, number of restos (they got quite a few 5-6 I think so got my fussy son's taste covered. It is also near Tokyo Tower. Staff are friendly, rooms are clean (with free electric flask so you get lovely Japanese green tea anytime! So nice! It is an old hotel, we can see some worn out carpet in our rooms but they are cleaned and the beds are good too. Perhaps they can renovate when they are no busy. It is a happening place so if you don;t like lots of people, choose a smaller hotel. But for us, we can avoid them plus, Japanese are usually courteous and friendly so not a problem, they are not noisy and very considerate.We love to come back!

It was our first time visiting Tokyo,Japan. This hotel was very convenient for us for the following reasons:-close to must see sites: Tokyo Tower (directly behind hotel), Zozoji Temple (beside hotel), Shiba Park (close walk)-free WiFi that was very fast-shuttle to Hamamatsucho Station: this is very convenient since this station is where most tours originate from. It is also where the World Trade Center is and they have a viewing deck with spectacular view of Tokyo-restaurants & convenience store within hotel: if you are lazy to go out, they have buffest breakfast,at Porto, japanese, chinese & other restaurants in the hotel and a lawson convenience store in the basement.Although the hotel is old it is compensated by the quality of service, cleanliness, and room size. I requested fir a room facing Tokyo Tower abd it was such a treat to see it at night from our window! We had a very nice stay and we thank our travel agency for booking this hotel for us.

This is a large older property. Probably last refurbished in the 70s or early 80s. It's a bit dated and tired. But, there are upsides which is why I rated the hotel a 4 out of 5. It's got a great location. Close to subway, a nice temple, park. The Tokyo Tower is right next to you. You can walk to Ginza in 30 mins or Ropongi in 20 if you want. The room rates are affordable and some rooms are spacious. Some are small. I had room 1032 on tenth floor and it was big and roomy. A giant bed and nice window and view. Staff were perfect and gracious. So overall I reckon this hotel is worthy of tourist consideration. Ask for a bigger room. I think the small ones might be a little unsatisfactory.

I saw Tokyo tower from my room!!there are nothing between the room and the tower. I love this view so much.This hotel located in the park.So there are green around the hotel even located in heart of Tokyo.Next to hotel,there are temple called "Zoujou-ji" so it's convenient to go there.This hotel has built 50 years but room was well maintained and cozy.If you like brand new thing,I don't recommend this hotel,but if you like old style,you will like it.

Perfectly acceptable regular, unspectacular Tokyo hotel as close to Tokyo Tower as you possibility could be and surrounded by loads of subway stations within 5/10 minutes walk.You feel the place is due an update and redecorate as it feels a little faded, maybe because of the preponderance of beige. Rooms are reasonable size. Good service and nice breakfast. Excellent, faultless free wifi in the room

Rooms - nice sized, extremely comfortable beds, clean, heated toilet was a luxury, thick walls with no noise from adjoining rooms, no morning clutter from hallway, xlnt water pressure, and nice workspace area/table. Very comfortable roomsAmenities - Had amazing view of Tokyo Tower from room. Toiletries were plentiful and no need to bring your own. US electrical outlets, no adapters needed, luxury beds and bedding a plus, tub shower was nice, nicely stocked convenience store in basement and several restaurants and a bar on premises, and Karaoke in hotel.Food - Breakfast buffet was high quality and variety. Omelet bar, asian or american style food.Staff - impeccable and polite, helpful, attentive, considerate and efficient.

I stayed with a group of friends who wanted centrality and connectivity throughout Tokyo. The tower was minutes away by foot and an underground was at the end of the drive up to the hotel. The hotel was large and inviting, plenty of parking out the front with valet if needed. The rooms were a good size, the front views out of the city and the Japanese Temple were good. There is a small shopping mall in the basement of the hotel which was quirky. Breakfast was good, and varied with both traditional and western style foods, and plenty of it.There are plenty of hotel offered services, including massage if wanted, but everything you would expect of a hotel so well situated.

We stayed here for 4nights (Dec17-21) and the room given to us was unexpectedly large compared to one of its chain hotels. they also provide free wifi in your room which has strong internet connection. Staffs are accommodating. Provides free shuttle bus (hotel- Hammamatsucho station roundtrip) but please check timetable. Also has airport bus which brings you directly to the hotel but we arrived around 9pm so we werent able to take advantage of that. Has restaurants inside hotel and a convenience store (Lawson). Very close (5mins.) to Tokyo Tower and Zojoji Temple. Its also around 20 mins on foot to Ropponggi station. They also accept luggage storage ( we requested for 1 week) and its real convenient for us for carrying less baggages going to Osaka. The hotel looks a bit old (since it was built many decades ago) but hope they would do some improvement to this. If Im coming back? maybe will check other hotels first in terms of their price rates.

Don't expect any frills. The hotel is very clean and the service is fine. However the beds are narrow, so if travelling with one child 3 beds is best. if you can manage to get a cheap rate go for it, otherwise there are better rates for the type of room in Tokyo to be found.

We stayed in the hotel for 7 days and had a very spacious room with a view of tokyo tower. Our room was very warm but could open the window to let some cold air in as the air con was not very good. The staff were very friendly and the supermarket downstairs (lawsons) was very reasonably priced. The green cleaning service is a brilliant idea, where you get money back for not having the room cleaned, which we used for 2 days. The metro is very close / 5 mi. walk from hotel. Wifi is free and works well inside rooms. Would recommend the hotel!

This is my regular Tokyo hotel. It's a bit old and run down but it's quite reasonable.It has a decent location, quiet rooms and fine restaurants. The convenience store in the basement is actually convenient.Tokyo Tower is 5 minutes away and Tokyo Station 10 minutes by taxi.

Despite its strategic location and the nice Tokyo Tower view from my room's window, I found this hotel to be very old. Refrigerator and TV keep causing strange sound whole night. Corridors are long, dark and rather spooky. Carpets show water marks. The door after the door concept of each room is also confusing. I thought I was mistakenly opening a cleaning service / janitor cabinet the first time I enter my room. Breakfast was nice anyway, but restaurant staffs are sometimes looking confused. Anyway, despite all those things, I had a pleasant experience staying in this hotel.

Business trip brought me to Japan. The reason why i stayed here is office arrangement (15-20 minutes walking to office)Like this hotel :1. Gave vouchers for shopping in hotel shop, since i decided to support on hotel's go green campaign2. Great breakfast experiences3. Lend me the universal adapter for the whole stay4. The staffs are very kind and support5. Near to the train station and gave great view from the room : Tokyo Tower. Transportation to airport is also easy (just order the limo bus @ the concierge)Dislike because :1. They are very strict on check-in time. Need to wait till 2pm2. Too old style, need to renovate. 3. Expensive. The room size is not equal with the price

Gate 1 put us at the Tokyo Prince Hotel and overall I had a good experience. The rooms were big and clean. Everything was centrally located and we took trains almost everywhere. I wish they had a work out room that would be my only complaint.

ごく平均的な都市ホテル。部屋は清潔、最近のホテルのように狭さは感じないが、何か魅力に乏しい。アクセントがないというのだろうか。Very standard city hotel. Room is clearn and rather spacious compared recent city hotels but something is missing or not very impressive.

I stayed here with my daughter for a short 5 day visit, the hotel is centrally located, always a taxi out the front to take you to wherever you want to go, the taxi drivers are so helpful & friendly & clean! The rooms were small but we weren't in there long enough to worry about it, 2 king single beds, the bathroom was adequate with all the trimmings (hairdryer, razor, soaps, shampoos etc.), we had a view out to Tokyo Tower from the 10th floor. The was a Belgian Café a short walk from the front of the hotel which we used every morning for a beautiful breakfast. The rooms were quite reasonably priced & the staff were easy to understand & helpful, we borrowed power adaptors, umbrellas & they were happy to translate & write directions for our taxi drivers in Japanese, would definitely stay again.

I have stayed in this hotel in Oct 2014 for 03 nights for business, price is around 200$ per night. It has closed view of tokyo tower, as it's from 80s so the hotel is quite old. It's close to train station but not so convenience to reach shops and stores. The room was small but clean. Breakfast was a little bit poor. It's just okay for me.

Loved to stay here in Dec 2013 with friends from all over South East Asia countries. Our room was just great because of the view of tokyo tower at night. Welll maybe it seemed old, the furniture yet it was soo clean in every inch. Breakfast was tasty and it was adapted to the season. Lovely stay!

I have stayed in this hotel in Dec 2013 for a night. It has the best view of tokyo tower but the hotel is very old. it is close to train station and i used the onarimon station to get around. the airport limousine service stops right in front of the hotel but the frequency is limited.i would highly recommend staying in this hotel during the new year eve as it is very close by to zojoji temple - in fact it is just next door.the staff are extremely friendly.we could leave our bags at the hotel while we travelled to kyoto for few days though we were not returning to stay after the trip.i would not hesitate to choose this hotel again if the price is right.

I booked this hotel in a package deal that had a great price for hotel and air. It's not a five star property, but for the value, well worth it. The room was medium size and clean. Service was excellent. Staff very accommodating and polite. Included breakfast was very good with lots of options. Location was good being located close to Tokyo tower, Zojoji temple, metro, etc. About 15-20 minute taxi to Tokyo station which was great if using J R pass to other cities. Lots of restaurants, etc.

Hotel was built in 1964 and is dated. Shows wear. Stayed at hotel as part of a tour group. Rooms were clean but there was scuffs and stains on walls and carpets. This hotel is ok for tour groups but would not be my choice if I booked a room myself.

The rooms can be a bit small, as they normally are in Japan, but comfortable. The food is very good, the atmosphere good but could be a bit more personal, I have enjoyed all my stays. It's central and a stroll over to the busy rapongi with its night life!

Tokyo Prince Hotel is located at the old part of Tokyo City, just walk distance to famous Zojoji Temple, Daimon and Tokyo Tower. This hotel can be reached by Oedo, Akasuka Metro and Mono Rail from Haneda Airport. Hotel Room is not very spacious but with wonderful services and facilities.Living here is more like a quiet corner in the central city but also very east to reach all the shopping places such as Ginza, Akihabara, Shibuya and Shijuku.
user_name:
Leo-Hoh
Sydney, New South Wales, Australia

review_body: We had a pleasant stay at this hotel for 4 nightsSeems like an older hotel but service was goodVery good buffet breakfast serviceGood location, convenient for pick up by tour operatorsConvenience store at basement is also good Walking distance to Tokyo TowerHotel staff are helpful

This is a typical and above average business hotel. But it's service, cleanness and facilities standard are higher than other 3 star hotels in Asia. The room size is bigger than the other downtown hotels as well. There are plenty of selections from the buffet breakfast, various from Western to Japanese cuisines. And you could sit closed to the window to enjoy the view from Tokyo Tower.It takes you 2-3 mins walk from the hotel main entrance to Onarimon metro station. From there you could get to Ginza, Shibuya, and Shijuku within 30 minutes by metro. There are several convenient stores (7/11, family mart) within 5 mins walking distance.Around the hotel, I would recommend you to visit Zojoji Temple. It's located next to the hotel main entrance. Its grounds contain the mausoleum of the Tokugawa family. It is lovely to walk through the grounds and immerse yourself in the Japanese style garden. I would not recommend you to get into the Tokyo Tower as it is nothing special from the other towers around the world. But if you still have energy after dinner, I strongly recommend you to walk to the closed by neighbourhood - Roppongi Hills. This is a newly developed area attracting for international visitors. There are some stores and restaurants as well as a variety of other facilities such as an art museum, and cinema. The viewing platform on the 52nd floor of Mori Tower above Roppongi Hills offers unbroken view of Tokyo Tower and the surrounding areas.There is only one downside from the hotel: Even the hotel guest will be charged JPY2000 per day to access to the hotel swimming pool. This is the only hotel that charges swimming pool access for its guests by far for me. I thought this rule could be optimised in the future.

We stayed for two nights for business, central location handy to transport.Breakfast was 23000 and was a large selection. The hotel is huge and does look like something from another era, but it was clean and spacious and had a bit of character about it. The staff were attentive. We did arrive early and were unable to check in before the designated 1400 and had to pay 10000 per hour for a late check out, I thought this a little inflexible for such a large hotel.

average quality of japan hotels.just the washroom is a bit old. Overall size is good.but we booked a 3 ppl room, they just arranged a sofa bed for the third person. which is a bit uncomfortable. the view is ok. you can see the main train station.

We spent seven nights in this hotel in Tokyo. The location is good, with easy access to underground lines, and about ten minutes from JR circle line. Large rooms for japanese standards, and huge reception and common areas, all spotlessly clean. Our room had a nice view over Tokyo Tower, which was a plus, particularly with the lights on at night. We had buffet breakfast at the Pikake tea salón almost everyday, and it was very good value, it starts at 9:am, ok if you're not an early riser! (of course there are other options for breakfast, but more expensive). Had dinner one night at the Tempura restaurant in the hotel, very very good. Service was great, as is the norm in Japan. The hotel concierge even arranged a reservation for dinner in Osaka very efficiently. All in all, the hotel deserves more than three stars

We stayed here for 3 nights and we found the hotel a bit dated but very clean and pretty spacious (what we didn't expect to have in the center of Tokyo). Location-wise - very well! Metro station Onarimon is just a five minute walk, the Tokio tower is also a five minute walk if you take the back exit of the hotel.The breakfast was nothing fancy and actually expensive compared to what was offered. Not much western food to choose - which is a little strange for this size of hotel. The french breakfast restaurant "le pain quotedien" just outside of the hotel has a very nice breakfast choice and the staff is perfect. Would recommend this to everybody whom don't want to pay a fortune,but still be in the very center of Tokio.

There is a nice garden surrounding it and within walking distance is the famous yokohama ramen in a small little shop. The best i have in Tokyo. You can see tokyo tower, very near distance. The subway is about 5-8 minutes walk. But walking through the garden is nice. Not many highrise building around is is a nice enviroment.

Of all the hotels I have stayed in Tokyo over the years, and comparing twin rooms only, this was by far the biggest room, really very spacious. Clean and with the usual amenities. The location is very good: it has a subway station on a corner of the property, a major temple on one side, and Tokyo Tower behind it and within walking distance.The two negatives -- breakfast was relatively expensive, and the hotel is in need of renovation.

The Tokyo prince is the older brother of the Tokyo prince tower. Both hotels are on the same property separated by a nice garden. For first timers in Tokyo this hotel provides great location and convenience to the "tourist sites". The Hamamatsucho station is a popular jump-off point for most of the day tours of Tokyo. The Tokyo prince hotels have regular hotel buses that travel to and from the station in regular intervals throughout the day seven days a week. This is the plus for this hotel as traveling in Tokyo is not easy and not cheap.Yes the hotel is really quite dated (the hotel still uses keys for the doors) and I wouldn't be surprised if it will need to give way to a newer high rise in the very near future. In the meantime, enjoy its value and location and the convenience store right at the basement.

Stayed here on a sports trip. Great location near Tokyo tower and temple, however very dated hotel. Small rooms and beds small by western standards. Approx5-10 min walk from nearest subway station.Good breakfast buffet. More a mid range hotel suitable to large groups of travelling Japanese. Was lucky enough to have a room facing the Tower which was great at night. Hotel in general stuck in the 70's.

The hotel looks like how you would imagine a 5-star hotel in Soviet Union during the 80's.All concrete with huge but worn out rooms. My room was clean with minimal furnishing.Breakfast buffet was ok. The staff is very friendly.Location is good with Tokyo Tower and Zojo-ji temple around the corner. You can catch the free hotel shuttle to get to Hamamatsucho and Daimon station.It's ok for an overnight stay, but personally this was my first and last time.

My first and last time at the Tokyo Prince Hotel.In 10 years I am visiting Japan, for both work and tourism, I never happened to be in an hotel like this. I even had cockroaches in my room (twice), quite uncommon in Japan.Air conditioning was not working: they just suggested me to open the window (!!).Stained room carpeting, overall appearance of a place that should be teared down for building something new.Stay possibly away.

Stayed on the last night of our trip. Check-in was easy, room was good size. Hotel shows signs of aging with inadequate upkeep. Expansive lobby with minimal furnishing, few places to sit. Dated front desk with very helpful and attentive staff. Long hallway to our room with carpeting overdue for replacement. Tile in our bathroom with widespread mildew. Seems to be a built-in problem of not having a fan in the bathroom rather than poor cleaning. The location of the hotel is very nice. We walked a few minutes to Tokyo Tower on our arrival and enjoyed the nighttime observatory views. It was a cool night, but the room was a little too warm with the non-digital thermostat turned down. In the morning, a pleasant 30 minute walk to Roppongi for brunch. Unfortunately, no time to see Warhol exhibit in Mori Museum. The hotel is in a nice location. It has a run-down appearance and feel. I would love to stay there again if there was a major renovation because it seems to have a lot of potential.

It's a reasonable location, but not especially close to any given station. Not far, but not exceptionally close. Of course it's immediately next to Tokyo Tower so you can end up with a pretty awesome view if you're on the right side of the hotel.The prices were quite reasonable, by far the saving grace of the stay. The hotel itself is showing it's age (built in 1964) and I'm not particularly convinced they've updated the furniture or carpet since the 80's, if not actually the 70's. It was nice to have a convenience store in the basement for those moments when you just couldn't bring yourself to go get real food.I can't say I was too impressed with the breakfast, as I only ate it once in the 20-someodd days I stayed in the hotel. The staff was, of course, exceptionally good, but this is Tokyo - what do you expect?I'd stay here again, but primarily due to the rates. Otherwise it's nothing particularly special.

Hotel right next to the Tokyo Tower and a temple. However, it was a 10 mins walk to hamamatsucho station. Can see the Tokyo tower from the hotel room which is the only good point. Staff was friendly and speak english well. There is a free shuttle bus to the train station though.

The hotel has quite a good location and reasonable prices. Service is good and staff is always helpful, as in general in Japan. Some stores are located in the basement and there is also some restaurants. Even if the hotel is clean, it is getting worn and some new paint and furniture would be nice. Attractions nearby include Tokyo Tower and a temple.

For our travel style where we use the hot water maker and fridge for our light dinner this is great. We like to do things on our own and not take tous so 5 days here was ideal. The breakfasts have everything - carbs, protein, veggie and Asian. Also nearby is loads of local restaurants. On our late arrival night, the ramen was comforting. Next door is a large temple complex and lots of green park areas are nearby. The hotel itself is older but everything is well maintained. Helpful staff and two subway stations nearby.

stayed there 3nights and had ok time. Had a pretty tiny room (assume the norm), reception area impressive huge and reminded me of an airport terminal. had an overall 70's thing going on, which is ok, but could have been a lot better and a lick of paint is much needed. The food was pretty good, nice breakfast buffet, bit pricey, but good. The location is good, close to several underground stations next to Tokyo Tower.

This tokyo prince hotel is one of the famous hotels in Japan.When i stayed at this hotel, this restaurant of this offers buffet of "Foie gras" which is very delicious.The bath room was made of "Marble".

My family and I stayed here to end our vacation in Japan. The rooms were pretty standard (a little outdated), nothing unique or outstanding. It's very central to transit and restaurants, so that was a plus. Front desk makes check-in easy and the valet service is quick and friendly.

I had one of those stays where it's difficult to complain but also difficult to compliment.The plus side: if you get the superior king bed room, you get a humongous bed that can sleep 3 Asian adults who do not turn much. And then there is space for two nightstands, a work desk, and a minibar with the TV on top. (The double room has two single beds and is smaller.) For Tokyo, that kind of space is a luxury. The place also has a bunch of restaurants albeit it's best to reserve. The restaurants are a notch about average. (See what I mean by difficult to complain but also to compliment.) We had a lunch, which was good, and then a dinner at the tempura restaurant. There's also a French/Belgian cafe on the hotel grounds and along the road. The hotel also has a small shopping arcade that houses a Lawson convenience store. It's pretty well stocked, including Tokio banana.On the minus side: the entire appearance of the hotel does look 1970s dated. In fact, there was a vintage car parade starting at the hotel carpark on the Saturday we were there.The location is not so convenient. It's off the Onarimon station, which is on a line that belongs to the smaller Toei group. If time is of some importance, try to stay around Ginza so you can more conveniently ride trains on the larger Tokyo Metro group.The room itself was comfortable. The toiletries were missing soap (only foam and gel), and the shampoo and liquid soap were both weak. Staff were helpful for the most part. I got help from Rosalinda and she was responsive and helpful. If your work takes you around the area or if you found a good deal for the place, I would say it's all right to stay. But if you are a tourist on limited time, you might want to consider something else.

Our room was very stylish. It looked like it hadn't been updated since the 70's, but it was in fabulous condition. It was a great value for the price. The staff was super friendly and we really like the area.

We stayed here for 3 days from 25th December, Front Office and Concierge staff very helpful fulfilled our request promptly.We had lunch at one of the restaurant on basement level friendly service and excellent food.Over all we had a wonderful stay

My second stay at the Tokyo Prince Hotel. Very convenient location for my business purposes, right next to the Tokyo Tower, and a great breakfast buffet included (both Western and Japanese dishes included). Very adequate for business travel. The pool is outdoor and only open in the summer.

My family & friends recently stayed in this hotel for 5 nights. The hotel's staff were very nice & helpful and most of the staff (especially in reception area) speak English quite fluently. The views outside the hotel room were very nice especially the Tokyo Tower. The room is clean and the size is quite reasonable and there is a Lawson Convenient Store at the basement of the hotel. The breakfast provided were OK. However, one of the limitation is that there is no WIFI in the lobby area.The hotel is close to one of the Subway but is a bit of walking distance to JR Station. However, the hotel do provide a free shuttle bus services to the JR Station.

We stayed in this hotel the last night in Japan. It would be a great place to start our trip as it was in the heart of the night life of shinjoku, for last night was a bit difficult to pack due to small room space. However the views were very nice from room the quality of the room was also pretty good, the only limitation was that wifi was not included in the price while in all other hotels we didn't need to pay extra for it. All in all it's good price for nice location, however be prepared to pay for wifi and small rooms.

I have stayed previously at Tokyo Prince about five years ago and have come back for a second 5 night visit. The staff were helpful, some if not most at reception, speak English. The hotel is showing its age but is still very comfortable and in a great location. We could walk to Subway, and circular Yamanote line easily. Breakfast a bit expensive but the Belgian bakery on the street out the front did a nice breakfast and coffee.

I stayed here with a school group. In terms of positives, they have a comprehensive breakfast buffet and a large area to eat breakfast in. We got in very late on our first night after an international flight, and I was very happy to see a Lawson convenience store in the basement, open until 11pm. The rooms are massive by Japanese standards, with room for a queen bed, a window seat to take in the great view of Tokyo Tower, a table and chair, and a desk and chair. On the negative side, it's a bit out of the way. It's a 15 m walk to the closest JR station and shops (besides the Lawson) or restaurants. It's obvious that the hotel is dated, and could do with a facelift.On the service side, the hotel failed to give us tickets for Tokyo Disney that we needed to get in, and we were only told about this when we got to the Disneyland gate. The hotel made up for it with free drinks in our mini bars, but didn't tell us! So we left most of them, out of fear of being charged.Overall, it's a decent hotel with a great view, but you need to be prepared to walk for a bit (or catch a taxi) to get anywhere.

This hotel is fairly old hotel, probably almost 45-50 years old but well refurbished and comfortable. Located at good atomosphere and yet convenient to most of part of Tokyo. Adjacent to Prince Park Tower Hotel which has various good restaurant.

I have stayed at this hotel a few times now and if you are looking for action at the front door you won't get it. Its a bit off the tourist route for that. Its a Japanese chain hotel that is frequented by the slightly older Japanese generation and a few tourists who stumble or see a good deal.The hotel looks as if it was built in the 60's and for Tokyo is very spacious. It has a huge car park (for central Tokyo) out front and is surrounded by temples.I would agree that there are parts of the property that are a little tired but here are the good bits:The rooms are far bigger than anything you will get in Tokyo at a similar price, you actually have room to move and open a suitcase here. The rooms I've found are always clean although some of the rooms are a little worn.There are 3 subway stations 1 JR station and a Monorail to Haneda airport all within walking distance. The Ginza is just a few stops away.Haneda airport is a short monorail ride and 520 Yen away compared to Narita at 3000 depending on how you go and Haneda is in my opinion a much nicer airport. Hammatsucho is a 10 minute walk away from the hotel, so bars and good local restaurants as well as western options are everywhere.Roppongi and Tokyo tower are also close at hand, you can actually walk to and from Roppongi if you want to save a cab or tube fare. Rooms on the back of the hotel have lovely Tower views.The hotel does have vending machines on each floor but more importantly has Lawsons shop in the basement for most of your needs.On the bad side: The breakfast is expensive for what it is, as is the food and coffee in the lobby. I do thing that this is a common problem in hotels though.The rooms do need attention and a refurb would be most welcomed.Overall though the hotel is very good value for money, cheap for its room size and setting.If you are looking for an action packed tourist experience, don't go there.However if you want a quiet base for business or pleasure, this hotel is well worth a try.Great central location, lots of food choices, and quiet. The tourist and shopping hotspots are just a few spots away in any direction.

Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam

review_body: We booked the Tokyo Prince Hotel because we heard the rooms were larger than average at decent prices. This was true but I wouldn't not worth the it. The staff was friendly, it's close to subway stations, views of Tokyo tower, and there is a vending machine that serves beer but those are the highlights.The hotel is old and in desperate need of a makeover. The sheets, carpet, shower, and sinks were old and dingy. You could tell the room was "clean" but it didn't feel that way. We originally opted for the bigger room without a view but upon arrival, we asked for a view. The only one available was a smoking room. We thought that a room with the smaller, smoking room with a view was better than the big room over looking the empty parking lot. There isn't much to do around the hotel so if you're looking for a hotel with action right outside the door, don't book here. There seemed to be a lot of tour companies having their guests stay here. Every morning, they would be a huge tour bus bringing dozens of elderly tourists to and from. We considered moving to an area with more nightlife but didn't end up moving. After checking out the city, we decided since we like action, people watching, dining out, we should have stayed in Shibuya. Rooms large. Cheap prices. Close to subways.

Reasonably priced room in an exciting area of Tokyo. Short walk to train transportation to move within the city. Service staff was very accommodating and eager to help.I would stay here again on future visits to Japan.

This place is where you want to be if you're planning on seeing the Tokyo Tower or spending any time in Minato or Roppongi Hills. It's a short walk or cab ride from Daimon station, which is convenient. Our room was very spacious compared to all of our other rooms throughout Japan on this trip, as is the bathroom. Lots of room to move around, comfotable temperature control and in-house dining (if desired) make this hotel a pretty good value. Nice gardens also flank the complex, making for some nice walking if you haven't had your share already. All in all, happy with our choice.

When staying in Tokyo I'd never been at ease with my hotel until I came here. It is wonderfully located - on my spare day I decided to book a tour but found that most things - Tower, Temple were within walking distance!! The grounds are lovely and for me- a runner- the circuits on the road and in the park is just fine. I liked the Lawson 7-11 in the basement and it is normally priced. I have to say that I did use it as an alternative to the restaurants which I found too expensive. There is a beer garden which is good fun and a pool. The rooms are very big but if you are on your own - 1 towel only! I thought the hotel was very much worthwhile and I'd recommend it to anyone.

Very peaceful despite it s size. Gardens beautiful and lovely to access - quite inspiring. Good service and staff all polite and helpful. Breakfasts had great variety in fact anything you could think of. Location. Wry handy got the station .

The hotel is very well priced for what you get. Efficient staff, clean spacious rooms conveniently located close to Tokyo Tower. Internet router in every room and shuttle bus to the train station. Some staff speaks English and are all ready to help.

KViking
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Nice Hotel - Located next to Tokyo Tower, Prince hotel is a very good hotel. The staff is friendly and the rooms were okay. This is a hotel that is great for people spending a lot of time in the city and want to sleep and relax in their hotel. Great location and great views of Tokyo. Rooms are small, but there are smaller rooms in Tokyo. Very clean. The Staff is super friendly and helped in every way possible. Will return. Recommended.

Located right next to tokyo tower, Prince hotel is not a bad hotel. The staff is friendly and the rooms were okay. This is a hotel that is great for people spending a lot of time in the city and want to get back in the evening and relax

Stayed over one night. I got a rather large room for being in Tokyo. Location is good. Close to Tokyo tower and few subway stations from Roppongi/Ginza. Breakfast is fine, mix of western/asian food. There is a Lawson in the basement. Currency exchange machine in the lobby. Good service at reception. Rather cheap to other hotel I have stayed in Tokyo (less than 15000 Yen/night without breakfast).

Fantastic view of the Tokyo Tower from my room. Very comfortable room, even with twin beds, we had enough space for big luggage and a lounge chair. Bathrooms were nicely size, very clean. Love the fact that the hotel encouraged guests to conserve water and be eco-friendly by offering 1,000yen shopping vouchers on days when we requested not to change the bed sheets. Short walking distance to the train station, very convenient.

NIce property, well situated in front of Tokyo Tower. Staff are efficient and polite and well versed in English. Buffet breakfast / lunch has good variety. Rooms are smaller than typical Western Hotels, but not cramped. Beds are very comfortable. Air conditioning and wireless internet work well. Bath has tub & shower w/ plenty of ot water. Very quiet area. Would easily recommend and stay there again. Several different restaurants on site. Shuttle bus service to/from Narita Airport (90 minute drive)

I stayed in a single room on the 7th floor. The room was a lot bigger then I expected. Decent size bed, decent size bathroom, big enough to fit a tea table and lounge chair, just. The t.v. Was actually a decent size(Japanese channels only though), and had an amazing view out the window of Tokyo Tower! I was in 775(?) so I think all the odd numbers were on the towers side. There is a lawson in the actual hotel complex in the lobby and a JTB cash money converter in the lobby also, which are both super convenient! Would only have to complain about the bed and the pillows, they were rock hard. The staff spoke okay English, but I didn't really speak to them much as I had a guide during my stay here.The actual location of the hotel is pritty good. There is a massive shrine next door which is well worth a visit. There is a main strip with both JR lines and Subway line on it, as well as resturants including McDonalds and Mos Burger. There is a big gate on this strip leading up to the shrine, you can't miss it. Just a short walk behind the hotel is the Tokyo Tower, which is a must! I went up at night and it was an amazing view and I would say the day time view would be very different but equally as amazing. A little tip if you get lost, head for Tokyo Tower you will pritty much always be able to see it! Stayed Early April 2013
