Perth, Western Australia, Australia

review_body: Huge rooms, delicious breakfast, fascinating view from the room.The bed surprisingly big, would be enough for 3-4 people. White furniture in classic style.The carpet was in stains but the room was still acceptable.
I was booking on INTERPARK TOUR in south korea. This hotel has very good price and good room condition.

I stayed 6 nights at the Prince Hotel while attending a conference. I paid $150/night including breakfast buffet and free in-room Internet. As others have pointed out, the property needs to be updated to be at the level of a top Tokyo Hotel, but this is a far better value. I would stay at this hotel again for many reasons. Location: it is away from the hustle bustle but walkable to Hibya; subway stop Onarimon on the Mita line is essentially on the property. Peacefulness: Like many Prince hotels, there is greenery on the property. Gorgeous azaleas were in bloom during my trip. You can walk next door to the beautiful grounds of the Zojo-ji Buddhist temple and buy incense from the monks, and access a large park behind it with flower gardens and people walking their dogs. The area is very quiet and you can get a good night's sleep - I heard birds instead of trains in the morning. My room was large enough to do morning yoga and Qi Gong, and I had a great view of the Tokyo Tower (Tokyo's Eiffel). While the hotel restaurants are expensive, there is a Le Pain Quotidien adjacent to the property with that delicious Euro bread and inexpensive red wine - no matter how much you like Japanese food, after 6 days you are ready for something other than salty fish fare! Le Pain is a huge plus in my book. Speaking of red wine, not to mention cheese: there is a Lawson convenience store in the hotel basement, open until midnight you can go down in your slippers! Rooms have refrigerators and hot water makers, and you know you're in a real Japanese hotel when the vending machines have beer. The bus to Haneda and Narita comes to the property. My bus to Narita stopped at a few fancy Ginza hotels, and noticing the crowds and noise I felt happy that I had stayed at the Prince.

Just checked in. Similar to other reviews agree that there is a very funky smell in the place. Only here for one night as it was the only reservation I could get. Room and bathrooms are extremely dated. Very strange as the space could be so much nicer if they upgraded, but I would bet they are planning on tearing it down and aren't putting anything into until that happens. Bathroom was so dirty that I started cleaning the doors, woodwork myself. Will post a pic of the grime. Size of the room was very good, so realize you are paying solely for size and location and nothing for room cleanliness, smell and decor.

Solid hotel, in a great location. Rooms quite dated and nothing to write home about, bit of a weird smell. Hotel in a very nice location and we had a good view of the Tokyo Tower from the room. F&B seemed overpriced. One good part is saying no to daily room service to get a JPY500 voucher - bought a few beers and saved the planet. :)Outside pool shut during our stay.

Good location if business in Minato and if want early jog in the morning around Hotel (see picture, park, temple, cherry blossoms and Tokyo Tower). Breakfast soso: they give discount vouchers but 2 out of 2 times 20 minutes waiting time for the "American Buffet". A la carte no waiting but no choice and food not specatcular. Japanese Breakfast no waiting time but not everybody's taste. Overall ok for business stay.

I stayed at this hotel for one night. The view was awesome because you can see Tokyo Tower from our window. Despite the view, I will not stay at this hotel until there is a renovation with the rooms. The rooms are old with a distinct odor which caused us to check out early. I originally booked this hotel because I was reading reviews and pictures look good. When I arrived, it had a nice lobby but the rooms were older. I wish I l knew about the strange smell. I would not stay at this hotel again.

We stayed here for 1 night. We arrived at checkin at was greeted and taken to the reception area, we had booked a non smoking double room. We was taken to our room and so was our baggage by 2 helpers.We arrived at the room and realised it was a smoking room! U could smell the old smoke smell! Not impressed! We didn't go back to reception as we wanted to get out and about so we decided to keep the room, the decor was awful....erm bright turquoise carpet and white walls! Was we In the Caribbean! Lol awfull! The room was a good size, bed was comfy but just very dated including bathroom. The room and hotel was clean so no issues there.The location is really good just 5 mins walk to the tower and 2-5mins walk to restaurants...OMG amazing breakfast cafe just down and the bottom of the car park on the right...Amazing Cakes and baked goods. It is also about 10mins walk to the local tube station, 5-10mins walk to a Starbucks & subway sandwich & family mart. Overall I like the hotel but it needs a big facelift! Nothing special! Only memorable for the nice cafe at the end of the car park. Hotel is also in a really good location but I would pay a little more and go somewhere else next time.

This was the second week long stay at this hotel. Both times have been very good. Location is excellent. Rooms are clean and have good-sized refrigerators.Nice views possible of the tower, or of the temple grounds. Multiple restaurants on site, all are good. Great selection of Japanese whiskey, too! Close to Roppongi and many subway stations. Helpful, foreigner friendly staff. If you need an ATM, go to the post office at the World Trade Center a few blocks away. Only problem this time was no climate control in the room, but fortunately the windows open.

Arriving from the airport it was just a short distance away once we crossed over the Rainbow Bridge. The Zinjo-ji Temple and the Tokyo Tower are adjacent to the hotel, so that was very convenient. There is a regulr shuttle to the train station, though it is only a 10-15 minute walk, also subway stations are close too. The staff were friendly and accommodating. The rooms were larger than we expected with the biggest double bed I have ever seen. Yes, it is a bit dated and the carpets could have done with a spring clean, but overall it was clean, comfortable, excellent breakfast, great location for touring around and the convenience store downstairs is incredibly handy if you arrive at an odd hour. This is one of the very few places I have been where the eco-friendly option works! If you have the limited cleaning service (no towel change etc) then you get a 500Yen voucher to spend in the convenience store or cafe downstairs.

Stayed a week here. Whilst the decor is dated, the staff are wonderful and the rooms well kept. An interesting mix of local business people & functions, 3 restaurants and a convenience store make life here very easy. Walking distance to central Roppongi & subway lines, yet nice and quiet of a night. Would happily stay here again.

The rooms are spacious, the rates are competitive and the location is central. What could be wrong? Well, as other guests have noted, the rooms have an odd smell. Even opening the window and going out for an emergency run of room freshener couldn't disperse the odor in my 10th floor room. If you plan to spend very little time in your room then perhaps it might be worth the price. On the upside the bed was spacious and comfortable and the in-room broadband wi-fi was free and glitch free. I was charged $25 for a buffet breakfast that promised an omelette station but no cook was on duty and the laid-out fare was pretty unappetizing. Definitely skip the breakfast unless it's included in your room charge.

We arrived just yesterday, october, 07, 2012, the room was with unpleasant smelt and the air conditioning does not work. The front desk ladie was very unpolite(in my personal view) and, to make things worse, she insist in charge us for three nights. All the reservatns sites charges 1 night in case of unjustified cancellation. Our cancellation is a very justified one. We are going to other hotel and we will try to make a honest and market practice cancellation. We do believe that this hotel way to make money is not sustainable.

Oh well we just stay there for quite few hours because of a sudden emergency landing from our trip. but we enjoyed our stay in Prince Hotel for we had a good rest and the food was ok. it was a free from our airline.

We stayed this hotel for a night only. The hotel does look a bit aging but clean. Room was fine. The staff were friendly. Our room faces Tokyo Tower and brights up at night. All amenities offered are standard but we can not complain. Breakfast was fine. This hotel is close to anything. Good choice for travelers.

Enjoyed my stay here. Big rooms, beds, good air conditioning, friendly staff (but not too overly friendly like other Japanese hotels), convenience store has tons of great stuff, very good breakfast buffet

I was here on a solo vacation. I arrived a bit early for check-in, they gladly took my bags and stored them while I spent some time at the temple next door. The location is great. Three different subway stops within walking distance - the train stop isn't much further. Tokyo Tower is a great view from the room, lights up at night and looks amazing. The rooms were a bit small (at lest compared to American standards), the door even hit the bed when opening from the hallway. Everyone was very English friendly, and it made for a convenient stay at the hotel. A bunch of great options near by for dining as well. I would recommend this hotel for someone looking to experience Tokyo. The staff was great in helping with directions and translations.

Milwaukee, Wisconsin, United States

review_body: A friend and I stayed at the Tokyo Prince during our trip to Tokyo. While not a luxury hotel, it was perfect for our needs since we were out most of the time anyway. The shuttle was great - once we found it. Unfortunately the night we arrived with our luggage we could not find it and took a long and winding walk to get to the hotel. The bus picks up in the bus station that is inside the World Trade Center next door to Hammatsucho station. As you leave the train, stay alert for bus station signs and follow them. The hotel was also extremely walkable from the train station. The room amenities were great. This may be a Japanese thing. There were toothbrushes and toothpaste, combs, and razors in addition to shampoo/conditioner/body wash. There was, however, no lotion. The internet was good once we got it working, and the front desk can loan you a tiny wifi router so you have wifi in your room. The breakfast was good, but expensive. It isn't mandatory though. I just tried it one day for kicks. There is a Lawson's convenience store in the basement. The beds were very firm, but extremely comfortable. I think it must be a different kind of mattress than what we see in the US.

Perfect for a couple of nights in Tokyo if heading off elsewhere in Japan. More of a business hotel but still has ace gadgets in the rooms from the early 1980s. Great views of Tokyo Tower from the rear rooms and close to a couple of subway stops as well as 10 mins walk from an overground station. Large clean rooms, great service and cheap if booked ahead or with a flight deal

We stayed for two nights prior to a cruise. The Hotel were very helpful in giving advice on the best way to get to Yokohama Port, going out of their way and ringing me on my cell phone with updates. English on the desk was patchy but for anything out of the ordinary they would get someone that had excellent English skills. The rooms were very nice, ours looked out on the Tower which is VERY close. Location was excellent. One block to Daimon metro and another 100 yards to the Hamamatsucho Station. It is well within walking distance but the hotel has a free shuttle service to the station every 30 minutes or so. Lots of nice places to eat within walking distance and lovely parks surround the Hotel. Zojoji Temple was nearly on the doorstep and is worth a visit. We got the metro to the fish markets (3 stops) but walked back to the Hotel afterwards. The stroll took about 40 minutes but there was not a lot to see between the Hotel and the fish markets.I left my Jacket in the room and wrote to them a month later when we returned home. They had the jacket and I gave them my CC details and I had it back home 2 days later. I doubt if that would happen at home.
Very peaceful, clean, friendly and convenient! Loved it and would stay there again.What a great place!

This hotel is in a great location. The rooms are well sized and they provide baby cots which is a bonus as we found many hotels in Tokyo city don't provide them. Free internet provided if you have your own laptop. There is a Lawson's convince store located in the hotel which is really handy as you can pick up food, drinks, snacks etc for quite a cheap price. The hotel is also a pick up point for the airport limousine and the Mt Fuji tours. Our baby got sick while we were staying at this hotel and the staff couldn't have been more helpful. They were able to help us get medical assistance and for the rest of the stay, staff inquired about the health of our child and provided ice packs etc.
Really great place despite small rooms. Good service and ideally located, close to basically everything. Walking distance to shrine and Tokio tower.

This Hotel is located within a few steps to the Tokyo Tower. I am an Eiffel Tower Fan and wanted to see this monument for my self. And it is such a nice tower you can have a visit to. The Hotel is located near the Rail stations that can take you around the city. THere are many Shops and Restaurants 5 minute walk. The only problem is that NO ONE SPOKE ENGLISH. Im glad we can do Universal signs and smile to get what we wanted. THere is plenty of room in all of the rooms . Showers are clean, Beds are confortable. and the Lobby Personnel is extremely helpful. I woul dcome back to this location again. ANd would recommend this to anyone . Families, Business travelers or Backpack travelers. Have fun in your search.

The hotel entrance can be confusing, we walked all around to find it at first. We booked a deloux room, but upon arrival, they gave us a standard room. We were too tired to pay attention right away. Later at night we noticed that it was a standard room, called the recieption and they changed the room and oppologized. We got the room we paid for, but t was a hassel to change late at night. Other than that, it is a nice clean hotel with spacious rooms and nice views.

I travel to Japan nearly every month (151 trips over 29 years and usually stay at Tokyo Prince Hotel in Minato-ku. For price and convenience, this hotel is super. The staff are friendly, the hotel is clean, and restaurant services very good. Internet is available and Prince Club/Prince Points rewards add to the experience. Recent renovation of the lobby, floors and rooms makes Tokyo Prince a second home when visiting Japan. I recommend as a first choice hotel.

This hotel is right at the heart of Tokyo. We didn't get a chance to try public transportation because we joined a fully escorted tour but everything seem accessible from here. The view from the room is toss between the Tokyo tower at the back of the hotel which sparkles and beckons at night. Or the nice Buddhist temple and Japanese garden in front of the hotel where Tokyo's sunrise can be amazingly beautiful in the early morning. There is an automated money changer at the lobby with English instructions which is very convenient. At the time we were there the exchange rate was 74.85 Jap yen to a dollar. A little better at the airport which was 78.80 to one US dolllar. So, if you change a $100, that would be around 400 yen difference which was roughly equivalent to 2 small bottled water and a gum. So the difference really depends on how tight your budget is. The tower is just a 5 minute walk away. With the cherry blossoms in bloom and an Early April temperature of 7 degrees Celsius, it could be a really pleasant walk.

A very spacious affordable hotel by Japanese standards. Located just behind the Tokyo Tower in a large open area, a novelty in Tokyo. Close to the Hamamatsuchho area, there are a lot of bars and restaurants within walking distance. A metro station is located just outside the hotel and there are many old Temples in the vicinity.The Hotel itself especially the exterior looks a little rundown but the rooms are still fine. renovation works seem to be in progress. Another plus point for the hotel is that the Airport Limousine (actually a bus) can be boarded from the Hotel( Must be because of the spacious parking).This hotel actually implements a environment friendly initiative, giving the guests a 500 yen coupon for every day you agree not to have your sheets/towels changed, for a maximum of 3 days. The coupons are redeemable at the Lawsons in the basement.All all a very good Hotel!

I stayed at the Tokyo Prince Hotel the first week of April with my 12-year old nephew, who wanted to travel to Tokyo for his spring break. The best part of staying there was how convenient the location was. It was close to the Hamamatsucho station on the JR Line. There is also a free shuttle bus that goes to and from the hotel to the station, which we appreciated on days when our feet were too tired to walk anymore. The hotel is also next to the Tokyo Tower, which we spent an afternoon at on a rainy day. The downside of the hotel is that it does not cater to English speakers. There were no TV stations in English and the staff spoke limited English. That was fine by us, as we had done a great deal of research in advance of our trip. Also, I hired for our first day in Tokyo an excellent guide, who took us to the Meiji Shrine (a highlight), toy shopping on Takeshita Street, and cruising on the Sumida River. Our guide also gave us a good introduction to riding the trains and travel trips for the remainder of our week. We were very fortunate to be in Tokyo when the cherry blossoms were blooming. The best viewing we found was in Ueno Park, which was very crowded on a weekday. I wouldn’t attempt to go there on a weekend. As we were jet legged having traveled from Minneapolis, we were awake early on our second day in Tokyo and did go to the Tuna Auction at the Tsukiji Fish Market. They only allow 120 people to go in each morning. We took a taxi from our hotel at 4:00 a.m. Make sure your taxi driver drops you at the right gate to line up for the tuna auction. When we arrived at 4:30 a.m. we were number 109 & 110 in line. Many people showed up in the dark after us and didn’t get in that morning. It was a terrific and unique experience. We also signed up for a day trip to Mt. Fuji and Hakone in advance of going to Tokyo. We were picked up at our hotel and spent a day riding a bus as part of a tour group. The weather was good so we saw Mt. Fuji. Some tours are two-days with an overnight in Hakone, but I am glad we only did this as a day trip. The highlight of the day trip was riding the Shinkansen Bullet Train from the Odawa Station to Tokyo Station. What a thrill!I had read that the Tokyo Prince hotel had a line of people when they opened the breakfast buffet and that was a problem. We only had breakfast early one day, the day we took our day trip to Mt. Fuji. The buffet opens at 7:00 a.m. and we went down for breakfast about 7:15 a.m. The dining room was crowded, but they open adjacent rooms to accommodate the demand. That is to say, we found the breakfast buffet opportune and tasty with both Japanese and Western items to select from. We did have every breakfast at the hotel, though we did not eat any other meals there. The hotel does not have room service, which we wish it did as there were a couple of times we did not want after a long day of touring to have to put our walking shoes back on to go find dinner.

I stayed here in May 2011 and was warned all about the small rooms to be expected etc. my room was fine. It was a decent size.The hotel is located near two different subways and you can cross a park to take a shortcut. The staff are very friendly and the experience is of a proper high end hotel. It feels luxurious, one of the best and most impressive I have ever stayed in.It is also very near the iconic Tokyo Tower, which is handy as this may help in not getting lost,mas Tokyo is pretty difficult to navigate around.

First day here and I am not dissatisfied with my room. It is not large or fancy but it is immaculate and the bed is very comfortable. The staff is very courteous and work through the language barrier to ensure they understand your need. The hotel is right by the Tokyo Tower and the Zōjō-ji Buddhist temple is next door. When I opened my window the night I arrived, I was thrilled to see I had a view of the Tokyo Tower. The Tokyo World Trade center is a few blocks away as is a main subway/train station hub (Not sure of their names yet). I haven't eaten at the hotel restaurant yet so I will add that when I have the details.

Certainly the hotel is old, with outdated everything but for a bargain $95 a niight (expedia) it was perfectly fine. My room has the Tokyo Tower in all its glory directly in front of it, it is well equipped with spa size bottles of soap and shampoos, hairdryer all the little amenities, razor, brush, toothbrushes, bath salts, nice size TV, hot water kettle, decent fridge, laptop size room safe, it is spacious and the window has a sliding fusama screen to block out the light and it is very clean. Plus it has its own " conbeeny", a Lawson's convenience store in the basement. Breakfast was either Yen 2400 for the full breakfast buffet or 1200 for toast, pastries, yogurt fruit, salad, boiled eggs, tea and coffee. Seeing what I have paid for breakfasts in hotels before this seems like a pretty good deal. What more can you ask for?

I stayed here over night on my way to Taipei, I liked the location a lot, very nice area to see the sights of the city it was very nice, friendly staff. The food was really good and breakfast was amazing the view was very pretty.My only real problem with this hotel was that it the room smelled very strongly of smoke it was very discouraging, as a non smoker.

Currently staying in this hotel and about to check out tomorrow. This is a decent hotel in a well placed location. Plus: the limousine bus from Narita Airport stops directly at the front of this hotel. It costs 3000 yen per person but nevertheless, makes the travel from airport to hotel a straightforward business. There is also a taxi stand right at the door step and a subway 3 minutes walk away which makes this hotel a very good base for sightseeing. There are a few scenic sights immediately in the area including a temple and the famous Tokyo Tower. Our room was kept absolutely spotless and the space is enormous compared to most hotels we've been to here in Japan (we've been to a few). There is a convenient store right at the basement which is open until midnight so for those who wants to save a few quid, this will help your budget. There are loads of eateries, cafes, restaurant around the area and you can be spoiled for choice. The only negative i guess is that the internet is not free. Most hotels, internet comes free. Currently, they are renovating but one wouldn't think they are as it is still very quiet. Then again we are on the ninth floor.

Although hotel and room are a bit dated, service is excellent and very clean. Good if you just need to sleep and have a base while touring Tokyo. Near subway and JR lines. Had great view of tower. Loved the credit option for not cleaning room which can be used for the convenient store.

The hotel is showing its age but it is very clean, comfortable with a charm about it. Very helpful staff and the food in the restaurant was very good. I would return as it is in a super location and ticks all the boxes.

This was an old hotel but we had a very comfortable stay. Very friendly vibe to the hotel. Rooms were spacious and good value. Excellent view of Tokyo tower from our room. Liked the eco friendly option for room cleaning - if you don't have your room cleaned you get a voucher for the gift shop. Overall, a very pleasant stay. Good location.

The Tokyo prince is à Nice starting point for any visitor to Tokyo. Location is central, but dont expect anything special of the hotel itself. Standard business style, ok for à few nights tough. Havent got anything bad to say about them, but if you are om holiday I guess there are much nicer places to stay.
Location was great if you're a walker. Close to the station. Lots of amenities in the neighborhood and a tranquil park a block away.

We stayed at the Tokyo Prince hotel in Minato (not the Tokyo Prince Park, which I hear is nicer) for a week, frm which we explored all of Tokyo as well as Kamakura and Nikko on day trips.I actually quite enjoyed the hotel. The location is in a quieter part of Tokyo - very peaceful at night, but just within a 2 minute walk to a metro station, and a 5 minute walk to a more lively part of Minato on Dimon Street.Hotel restaurants were overpriced (didn't eat there at all), but countless options for food nearby. Rooms are decently spacious for Japanese city standards, and clean -- as long as you don't move the furniture around to reveal HUGE dust bunnies.Pool only open in Summer, so can't comment on that (not that i probably had time for swimming anyways!).Staff at concierge desk were pretty useless, only helpful to ask for maps of the metro, as they couldn't advice anything else, from were to eat, to what to do or how to get around... they didn't even know what a JR pass was!Other than that, quite enjoyed the hotel and th great view of the Tokyo tower from our room!

Walking into The Tokyo Prince Hotel is like traveling back in time. It really appears like nothing has been replaced or updated since the early-mid twentieth century. Having said that, the rooms were clean and the staff courteous and helpful. The breakfast buffet is monstrous but is constantly overrun with people. The hotel charges nearly 2000 yen per day to use the gym or swimming pool, and internet access is charged by the minute or for a 24-hour period (you have the option depending on your anticipated usage). If you want to be by The Tokyo Tower you can't really get any closer. But if you're a first-time visitor to Tokyo, it's not really the area you want to be. There isn't much going on relative to Shinjuku, Harajuku, Shibuya, etc.

Hotel is just next to Tokyo Tower, you'll be able to see the Tokyo Tower from your room if you're lucky to be assign a room facing it. The deluxe rooms we have are big, although we had problem with their aircon which was not functioning well. They have free shuttle service to nearest train station which is a 15 min. walk from the hotel. Very ok to take a walk to the train as the way is full of very affordable restaurants and convenience store. Hotel also has airport limousine bus pick up for a fee of 3,000 yen per pax. They give refund of 1,000yen in gift voucher per room if you wont avail of their housekeeping during your two nights (min.) stay. You may use this voucher to purchase goods within the hotel stores and restaurants only.

We got an awesome deal staying at the Tokyo Prince for nine nights. We requested a room on an upper floor with a view of the Tokyo Tower and they accommodated us perfectly. The view of the tower was incredible, especially when it was lit up at night. The room was smallish by American standards but perfectly adequate size-wise. It definitely was not shockingly small like I'd been warned about Tokyo hotels. The bed was hard, being pregnant this was a definite downside. Walking all day around Tokyo and then sleeping on a hard bed made me very sore. I would guess that a more Western hotel would have the softer beds? There were three train stations near the hotel, one was a five minute walk, another a ten minute walk, and the one we used most often was fifteen minutes from the back of the hotel. The hotel had very expensive restaurants and the tea room was extremely over-priced. We only tried the tempura restaurant and it was not great to our palettes but it was crowded so I'm guessing others liked it. The restaurant was gorgeous, though. We never ate at the tea room since it was way too expensive. I was glad I had brought lots of breakfast foods with me to eat in the morning and then we ate around town the rest of the day.The hotel staff was very friendly and nice. You definitely had to know Japanese to be able to communicate with them however. We would always try speaking English and then resort to Japanese to get our full point across. I imagine if you didn't know any Japanese you would not be able to ask them about how to get places or recommendations very easily at all. You would just have to tell them very basic things in English. They didn't have an ice machine but were willing to send ice to our room for free. The tub was very deep and nice. The heated bidet/toilet and heated steam-free mirror were pretty fun, too. Overall, it was a great deal, and we loved the view. Probably not the closest location, depending on what you wanted to see. (Very close to the fish market, however). But you can get to everywhere using the trains.

The Tokyo Prince is located in a green oasis within the city, within easy walking distance of the Emperors palace. The lobby & the rooms are spacious. Breakfast room was like a zoo, very busy & Expensive especially in USD terms with an 80Yen Exchange rate.Swimming pool is outdoors so no chance to swim in the winter time, really nothing worng with the hotel , this just isnt my favorite location, it doesnt feel in the heart of the city & that is beacuse it isnt. If you like a more peaceful envionment, this this is the hotel you are looking for.

All the staff were friendly everywhere and on their best -behavior to all customers.The hotel was old, but feeled like kinda tradithinal .Best to stay watching "Red shining TOKYO tower".Need to confirm the room reservation is tower-side or not.All you have to do before check-in is try to choose better room to see the tower.

The hotel is located in the business district of Tokyo & is within walking distance from Tokyo Tower. It is convenient to walk to many shops & restaurants, as well as 2 train stations. The staff was very helpful. They actually went online to research the answer to our questions. The room was pretty large (for Tokyo size). The room was clean & the bed was comfortable. The Japanese restaurant onsite was pretty good & not too expensive.

Service could be better staff could be more polite and helpful especially the staff at the reception. Night view of tower is very good. Room and amenities are good. It is neat and clean but some areas require renovation. Location is very good and is between two local train stations. Conference halls are spacious and alright.Food was bad!!!!

We booked a superior room with a king size bed. Room was spotless clean but decor very dated. Everything worked and the room itself was very large and the bathroom Ok. Easy walk ( 10 minutes), even towing a large suitcase each, to JR station Hammatsucho near World Trade Centre on the loop line and 2 subway stations. Quite a few restaurants on the way.Check in easy and even let us check in 2 hours early.Tip- if you don't have your room serviced every day you can get a 1000yen voucher to spend in the hotel. Buys take away Japanese bakery breakfast for two at the hotel shop in the basement level!Negatives- Hotel pool 1000 yen per person, per swim for guests = exorbitant for a very average pool. Dont't even think about the 2000 yen for a sunbed! No free internet..........Not sure about the staff knowledge and service as to after my first failed attempt to have a question answered I gave up and worked it out myself!

We stayed there 5 nights and had a good time. After getting a tiny room (must have been a single-room), getting upgraded to a bigger, but dirty, smokingroom, we finally got a nice big room. The reception area was huge and reminded of some transportation terminal, there was even a taxi-stop outside the hotel, filled with taxis. The hotel had an overall 60/70-feel to it, which is ok, but could have been better maintained. A bucket of paint would have done wonders for the place. The hotel also had a small shopping mall in the basement, with a small convenience-store, your usual souvenirs, but also furniture and 1 000 000-yen priced purses (and that was on sale!). We found all this very strange for a mid-range hotel. The food was good, both the full breakfast buffet and the light breakfast buffet were good, and the japanese style had both good sushi and tempura meals. A bit pricey, but good. As for the pool, we didn't use it because they charged 1000 yen pr day, even for the guests, and tattoos were actually not permitted in the pool area! The location is good, close to several underground stations, and right by Tokyo Tower, which is actually pretty cool. The view of Tokyo by night from 250 meter is awesome!The room we finally got was ok, good size and a good sized bed. The bathroom amenities were also good. The personell were friendly and polite. All in all we had a nice stay.

I was already disappointed upon arrival as I made the mistake of booking the "Tokyo Prince Hotel" at the Tokyo Tower, as opposed to my intention of booking the "Prince Park Tower Tokyo" which is right next to it. Both of them are Prince hotels - be careful not to make the same mistake!The Superior rooms face the swimming pool, not the Tokyo Tower which we wanted, the receptionist did not recommend the standard rooms...OK. So the room was clean, but old. You could see on the appliances that the white plastic was already beige and so. However the high point was the bed: it was 2.3m wide (close to 8 ft)! Amazing, I've never seen such a big bed. Also the room was pretty large, 35 sq m (~400 sq ft).The receptionists spoke English, but the concierge was really incompetent and the limousine/ shuttle services were badly organized. There is a free shuttle to the closest train station, but it stops by other hotels so you end up getting there slower than if you went on foot! The airport shuttle is equally inconvenient: it takes 3 hours because it stops by other hotels too. It is better to take a cab to the Tokyo station and the train - we were at the airport in 1.5 hours.The concierge service was incompetent: we were trying to get to Odaiba Island and the person first looked at the map then still could not tell which is the correct metro/train to take. At the end he recommended two connections where one was enough on our way back. This Odaiba Island, if you aren't familiar with Tokyo, is like Central Park in New York. So imagine you stay in a hotel on Manhattan, ask the concierge how to get to Central Park and the guy has no clue...The Swimming pool was another low point. The whole pool is about 3-4 ft/ 1.1 m deep and the water was way too warm, you can hardly swim in it. Despite that the ask $15 per person from hotel guests to enter the pool. If you want to sit on a sunbed, it is another $30, and these sunbeds are at least 10-15 year old, white plastic already with a brown tint from the sun, not very appetizing. Give me a break!The Business Center worked well, fast internet connection, working printer.

Located in a good posititon, in central tokyo, 10 min. walk to the subway. Free shuttle service to Hamamatsucho subway station. The hotel is overall good but a bit old, in particular the furniture in the rooms. You get your sheets changed everyday but the room is not cleaned very well, smells dusty. It can be fine for one or two nights.

We chose the Tokyo Prince for its OK location and less-than-exorbitant price on our first trip to Tokyo. It turned out to be a good choice.The place has the advantange of being literally next to the Tokyo Tower, which makes it very easy to find even for a newbie tourist at night, the Tower being visible from everywhere.The only thing I did not like too much was the "antique" room style with table and cabinet painted white. It was neat and clean though.

This hotel is outdated so don't expect the latest technology or modern furniture, but it's basic and clean so serves the purpose. It is conveniently located on the corner of a subway line and directly next to the Tokyo Tower. Daimon is a 5 minute walk with access to a main JR subway line and also bullet train station. Roppongi is a 15-20 minute walk in the opposite direction with lots of restaurants on offer ranging from traditional Japanese to Italian, Mexican, American and various other Western options. Toji Temple is also directly next to the hotel offering great photo's and culture on your doorstep. There are 4-5 restaurants in the hotel and we had sushi one evening at the secluded Sushi bar. I was a little disappointed in the quality (given that we were in Japan I expected it to be the highest level/grade sushi) and the chefs are not willing to deviate from the menu at all so you are forced to order only from the limited options they have (I'm pregnant so was trying to order only the cooked fish - ie. shrimp/crab but they didn't understand me at all). The staff in the hotel are helpful and friendly, but sometimes the language barrier proves an issue as their English is limited. The breakfast buffet was excellent with lots to choose from but be warned, it opens at 7am sharp and on the days we went at this time there was a long line out the door waiting for tables. So you're better off heading down a little later and not having to wait - the same options will still be available (minus perhaps cereal one morning as all the little boxes has already been taken). So all in all a good hotel with all the amenities you may need on a basic level. I would stay here again and indeed recommend it, so long as you are aware of the condition and minor issues mentioned above.

My husband and I just travelled to Tokyo during our Easter break. We had done all the right things by letting the hotel know that we'll be arriving late as our flight landed at 7pm in Narita. We had been told we'd get a king sized bed but when we got there, they had already passed it on to someone else. Not a big thing as they managed to get it for us the next day. However, I didn't find that they were willing to help or were more grumpy because we were asking for something they should have given to us in the first place. The hotel room was huge and the bed was comfortable so we had really good sleep. In terms of decor, it is definitely a bit outdated but considering for what we had paid for it, we didn't mind it at all!!! It is not too far from the JR line or the subway as well as good food places (about 10mins walk). I'll definitely recommend this hotel if you want comfort in terms of room and space and if you are not going to be reliant on the front desk for information.

Stayed here as it was tied in to a consolidator airfare we were able to purchase. This large and aging hotel is not located near anything of note in Tokyo, but is also not so far away that a 20 - 25 minute walk won't get you there. It is located near several subway stops (easily the best way to get around Tokyo) and about a 15 minute walk from a JR line station. There are a number of reasonably priced places to eat within a 15 minute walk. The hotel itself is large and has the look of an East Bloc hotel from the 60's (not very Japanese) with adequately comfortable rooms and very pleasant staff. Rooms, while not particulalry large, were clean and reasonably comfortable. The buffet breakfast is costly but generous and served in a large and bustling room full of global travelers. Reasonable value and 3 star comforts.

We chose the Tokyo Prince Hotel after searching for 4 star properties on the internet. Despite what other reviewers have said, this hotel is value for money, is clean, located in a great area and offers exceptional facilities. The rooms and the common areas are a little dated however the carpets in the main areas have now been updated and make the property modern again.The hotel is near a number of subway station. The nearest JR station is about 20 to 25 mins walk, but the hotel provide free shuttle service to and fro the JR station. Just make sure you check the bus schedule and prior booking from the hotel to the station is required at the travel desk. Alternatively, just take a short walk to the station. The streets leading to the station is lined by cheap and good food. Do look out for a ramen shop that is beside Yoshinoya. Very very good pork base soup! A must-try!The breakfast buffet is quite good, but the surroundings somewhat uncharming. There is also a sushi restaurant which is supposed to be really good. Alternatively, the Roppongi district nearby is buzzing with restaurants. Ginza shopping area is a 10 minute taxi drive away, unless you opt for the efficient subway system. This hotel is a strangely fascinating, reasonably priced, and a very good choice of accomodation in central Tokyo.

I bought an online package including return air-tickets and hotel stay. My husband and I stayed at the Tokyo Prince Hotel for 9 nights.The room was spacious that even had a small armchair and coffee table beside the bed. The bathroom comes with a large bathtube, which is quite welcoming after the long walks around the city. Do request for a room facing the tokyo tower as it is a really nice sight at night when the tower lit up in the warm orange lights.I was also plesantly surprised that I can opt not to have house-cleaning service and in returen, we were given a 1,000 yen hotel voucher each day. This option can be used no more than two consecutive nights (ie you have to clean your room every three day of stay). The voucher can be used at the hotel restaurants, shops and even the convenience store. In the end, we bought the food items as gifts to our friends and family. More information can be obtained from a slip in the room.The hotel is near a number of subway station. The nearest JR station is about 20 to 25 mins walk, but the hotel provide free shuttle service to and fro the JR station. Just make sure you check the bus schedule and prior booking from the hotel to the station is required at the travel desk. Alternatively, just take a short walk to the station. The streets leading to the station is lined by cheap and good food. Do look out for a ramen shop that is beside Yoshinoya. Very very good pork base soup! A must-try!All in all, I feel that the hotel is not bad. The hotel staff are generally helpful and they are able to communicate in English. I will recommend it to anyone who like a comfortable room and not keen to pay too much.

Stayed 4 nights and the Tokyo prince hotel, my friend had found a REALLY cheap deal on expedia.com.au Room was nice pretty decent, nice big double beds great shower.The hotel is serviced directly by the airport limosine so no having to change metro or traipse around a busy city looking for it. If you dont have your room cleaned for one day they will reimburse you with a Y1000 coupon to use in their restaurnts or convience shop, great for buying some beers and snack food. 20minutes walk or so from roppongi, 5minutes from tokyo tower. Once you get your sense of direction quite a few metro stations 5-10minutes walk awayAll in all a super hotel for the price!!

I transferred to this hotel after first staying at a hotel near Shinjuku. Staying at the Tokyo Prince was such a relief in comparison to staying in the crowded Shinjuku area and is also located near several train lines. The Tokyo Prince is located next to the Zojoji temple, which is a peaceful and interesting place. Also, for about the same price of the hotel I paid at the Shinjuku hotel, I got a room that was more than twice the size and a nice view of the Tokyo Tower (non-refundable double room price on expedia). Will definitely stay there again.

My friend and I stayed at Tokyo Prince Hotel for 21 nights. We booked using hotels.com, and we paid about 100$ a night for a room with two single beds (very cheap for Tokyo!). The room was wonderful- spacious in Tokyo standards, with a mini fridge and everything we needed, plus our view was right on Tokyo Tower! The staff was so kind and helpful and spoke English pretty well. The restaurants of the hotel are a little expensive, but there are many other restaurants in the area. Furthermore, the hotel provides a non-cleaning service: guests can specify a few days in which their room won't be cleaned, and for every non-cleaning day you get a 1000 yen (about 10$) coupon for the hotel's restaurants and convenience store.The hotel's location was perfect for us- just a few minutes walk from Daimon subway station and Hamamatsucho JR station. From there you can get to basically anywhere you want, and the JR Yamanote line takes between 5 to 20 minutes to get to the main districts of Tokyo... :)The hotel was also very clean, including the room.We enjoyed our stay at Tokyo Prince Hotel very much, and I would recommend it to anyone who wishes to spend some time in the lovely city of Tokyo!
Good service, good environment, good view of Tokyo Tower from some rooms,

On our first day in Tokyo, we had stayed at a ryokan (but that turned out to be really disastrous), so we booked ourselves into Tokyo Prince (via planet tokyo).The Tokyo Price is located very close to Onarimon train station and the Zozoji shrine. There is an AMPM at walking distance-- so full marks on location.While the hotel has a 70s feel to it and the rooms are not wi-fi enabled, they are clean and comfortable.The Tokyo Prince is definitely value for money and i would therefore recommend it.

We stayed in this hotel for three nights, and it was basically just as reviewers had previously described. Positives: relatively inexpensive, very good location, close to subway, and moderately spacious. Also, you can forgo having your room cleaned and use the $10 at the convenience store. Negatives: rooms appeared a little outdated (but not a big deal to us), not the best location in the city.Overall, I would recommend the hotel based on its value. I would stay there again. As an aside, some have stated that this hotel is located in Roppongi. This is untrue. It is a very long walk to Roppongi, if you want to go there (which we didn't).

fantastic hotel (chique and good priced) near Shinagawa station (to the inner city, Narita, Yokohama, Kyoto, etc.) with beautiful garden. We had big room with gardenview (12 etage with also great view on parts of Tokyo). Quiet and so close to the crowdy inner city (within 20 minutes in Shibya, Ginza, Yokohama, etc.). Take also an Japan Railpass!!. And they are so polite, everything is so clean, eatingprices are normal European standard (read cheaper than Amsterdam). Do it. And go also to Yokohama Chinatown and the harbour of Yokohama (and if possible visit Yokohama Arena for the K1). Also visit Kamagura, Harajuku, Asakusa, Odaiba and the nightlive in Roppongi. Visit also the Belgian cafe The Hemel in Shibuya. And the MOSburgers are three times better than Mac or BurgerKing. Japan I Love it.
Tokyo Prince Hotel is in a great location near Tokyo Tower and is well priced. The rooms are really comfortable and clean. I would definitely stay here again.

We chose the Tokyo Prince Hotel after searching for 4 star properties on the internet. Despite what other reviewers have said, this hotel is value for money, is clean, located in a great area and offers exceptional facilities. The rooms and the common areas are a little dated however the carpets in the main areas have now been updated and make the property modern again. We joined the Prince Club International membership scheme (free) and this gave us a rate of Y165 000 per night including western buffet breakfast in the Porto restaurant which was great value. The hotel is located next to Tokyo Tower and also some great Buddhist temples - a good day of sightseeing right at the front doorstep. We ventured over to the sister property, the Prince Park Hotel (5 minute walk) which was also a nice property. We used the onsen facilities and also the coffee shop which proved to be great Japanese experiences during our stay. the rooms at the Tokyo Prince were small yet comfortable and out view looked over the Tokyo Tower which certainly was a sight to behold at night time. We trevelled to tokyo in February which is still winter however each room at the Tokyo Prince was centrally heated and it was nice to come home to this after a hard day of sightseeing. Overall, a great hotel that has exceptionally freindly staff and excellent facilities for the middle-of-the-road traveller.

The location almost just underneath the Tokyo Tower, and with a subway station on the corner, and Roppongi just a short stroll away, makes this a great choice, considering the moderate room rate. Also it is relatively close to the fish market, and to the pier for river ferries, and the area in general is quite pleasant. In some ways, the hotel is Japan in a nut shell: Small, but incredibly tidy rooms, correct and polite service, and impecable maintenance of old things (such as the decor and furniture). When you enter the room, it is like stepping into an early James Bond movie. Nothing has been changed since it opened (late 60s, 70s?), and it still looks relatively new, due to impecable maintenance. Fascinating and very Japanese. The toliet seat is new though, and has more swithces than an aircraft cockpit. Amusing and also very Japanese.The kimonos and tiny slippers adds to the whole Japan experience, and there is tea and a waterboiler available in the room. The breakfast buffet is quite good, but the surroundings somewhat uncharming. There is also a sushi restaurant which is supposed to be really good. Alternatively, the Roppongi district nearby is buzzing with restaurants. Ginza shopping area is a 10 minute taxi drive away, unless you opt for the efficient subway system. This hotel is a strangely fascinating, reasonably priced, and a very good choice of accomodation in central Tokyo.

After having a bad experience of spending a night at another Prince Hotel (Shinagawa) we found this hotel . It is clean, quiet and very comfy. We had the view on the Tokyo tower, quite "flashy" at night ! The service was extra fine, employees so helpful. The only thing wrong with this old hotel: it needs to redo their rooms that are quite outdated. Beside this we recommend it.
